According to official statistical data on eCall, it is estimated that the full introduction of the system in cars in EU Member States would save 2 500 lives annually, while reducing the severity of injuries by 10-15%. However, the mandatory deployment of a public eCall should not be based or made conditional on the existence of a positive business case for the standalone eCall service. Its benefits for society as a whole should also be considered. eCall should be a public emergency call service, free of charge, for the benefit of any driver in Europe regardless of his make of car. A mandatory public eCall could be the enabler for the take-off of many other commercial services, which are ready for the market but still need a killer application to be successful. Therefore, eCall could support additional public or private telematic services providing further safety and economic benefits.

intervention.name: Sebastian Valentin BODU
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: According to estimates, the upshot of the eCall system, which is triggered automatically as soon as the in-vehicle sensors detect a serious accident, will be to speed up the arrival of the rescue teams by around 40% in urban areas and by 50% in rural areas. If it is used on a large scale, the eCall service will help save hundreds of lives in Europe every year and reduce the severity of the injuries and trauma in tens of thousands of cases. Based on what has been said above, I support this report and I think that eCall must be a public emergency call service provided free for the benefit of any driver in Europe, no matter what make of car they drive.

intervention.name: Philippe BOULLAND
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report on the eCall system: a new ‘112’ service for citizens. This system constitutes a genuine technological advance: it enables an emergency call to be automatically triggered, whether the car is damaged or not, whilst sending out a message including key information about the accident, such as time, accurate location, driving direction, vehicle description and whether the passengers are conscious or not. This system, which can also be activated manually, functions on the basis of the single European emergency number 112 combined with the vehicle’s satellite positioning. According to estimations, the implementation of such a system in cars should save the lives of 2 500 EU citizens annually and reduce the severity of injuries by 10 to 15% due to better responsiveness from emergency services. The eCall system is dormant until an emergency call is triggered. The principles of privacy and protection of personal data are therefore fully respected, this being an essential condition for the system’s adoption. Furthermore, technological neutrality is guaranteed with eCall so that car manufacturers can remain free to choose the system they install in their vehicles.

intervention.name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
intervention.p: The reason why I voted in favour of introducing the eCall system is the need to speed up the arrival of the emergency services, save lives and reduce the injuries caused by road accidents. According to estimates, the eCall system could save up to 2 500 lives a year. The required technology is already available at EU level, and the Commission is making Member States update their response systems so that they can handle eCall calls by 2015. My view is that eCall should be a free public emergency call service for the benefit of every passenger in Europe, no matter what make of car they drive. The faster arrival of rescue teams, the police and recovery firms allows the accident scene to be cleared more quickly, thereby reducing external costs. The benefits of eCall for public authorities lie in the reduction of the medical consequences of an accident, of the risk of a further accident at the same location and of the impact of an accident on traffic. Similarly, in the case of the car industry, introducing an eCall service on a compulsory basis in every new type-approved vehicle will open up new opportunities for implementing additional services offering added value.

intervention.name: Alain CADEC
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I welcome the European Parliament’s adoption of the Koch-Sehnalová report. This new eCall system for EU citizens could save up to 2 500 lives annually. Indeed, this new 112 service will, in particular, enable road accidents to be handled more efficiently due to the faster arrival of emergency services at the accident scene. Furthermore, I feel that the compulsory nature of this measure is a good thing, as a voluntary approach has not achieved significant progress to date. It would be wise to extend this system to all new vehicles in the EU.

intervention.name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
intervention.p: The eCall service automatically triggers an emergency call in the event of a severe road accident. In order for this to happen, the vehicle must be equipped with the eCall service. eCall does not prevent accidents, but it does make the emergency services more effective. I voted for this report, as I believe that installing the eCall service should be mandatory and should not be based or made conditional on the existence of a positive business case for the standalone eCall service, as its benefits for society as a whole should also be considered.

intervention.name: Françoise CASTEX
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Earlier today, we voted in favour of the general introduction of eCall, an in-vehicle emergency call system. This system, which is public and open, could contribute significantly to reducing the road death toll. That is why we have been advocating it since 2003. Unfortunately, for commercial reasons, car manufacturing lobbies want to impose private optional systems, which was supported by France’s former government which did not wish to invest in the scheme, and by several French MEPs from the Group of the European People’s Party (Christian Democrats). Saving a life does indeed have a financial cost, but it is our duty as European law makers to show that, with a high-performance safety system, the EU can and must protect citizens. We are now waiting for the Commission to propose legislation quickly so that the system can become operational throughout the European Union by 2015.

intervention.name: Carlos COELHO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The deployment of the eCall service, based on the 112 emergency number, should ensure the automatic notification of the emergency services in the event of a serious accident. As such, it will make a key contribution to reducing the number of fatalities on European roads, as well as mitigating the consequences of injuries due to faster, qualified and properly equipped assistance. This pan-European emergency call service from vehicles should operate in all Member States and European countries associated with this initiative, and should be available in any vehicle, irrespective of make, country or actual location of the vehicle. Initially, this service was expected to be completely operational by 2009. Unfortunately, progress has been too slow, and the roll-out of the pan-European eCall service has been further delayed. It is therefore imperative to ensure that this system, which is considered one of the most efficient yet low-cost as regards road safety, can be deployed in a timely and streamlined manner across Europe, as is indeed desired by 80% of citizens surveyed. I support this initiative, which enables the establishment of a regulatory framework for rolling out this service, and which will speed up the process and make the installation of eCall devices obligatory in all new type-approved vehicles in Europe.

intervention.name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Member States have set their sights on reducing the number of fatalities and traffic congestion during such incidents, and on improving the way events of this kind are handled. I think that the eCall service can make a significant contribution to doing this, especially when it comes to reducing the period of time taken by the specialist emergency service call-out teams to arrive on the scene.

The confidence that European citizens have in these services is important when they are travelling in other Member States. This is why it is beneficial to incorporate the eCall service in every vehicle, no matter what make it is, in which country or where its current location is, as well as to implement the eCall in-vehicle components quickly without any intermediate stages.

intervention.name: Rachida DATI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I gave my full support to this text, which proposes the integration of an automatic emergency call system in all EU vehicles. I voted in its favour not only because it could save lives, but also because it makes this system a springboard for technological innovation in Europe. Indeed, the report recalls the need to link eCall with existing satellite navigation systems (EGNOS, Galileo, and so on), and encourages the future integration of innovative in-vehicle services.

intervention.name: Christine DE VEYRAC
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Although in-vehicle automatic emergency call systems are a good initiative to enable faster responses in the event of road accidents, I chose to abstain from voting on this text, which aims to implement a pan-EU system, called eCall, which would be compulsory for all vehicles. It is indeed my understanding that road safety is the responsibility of Member States. While our Member States are committed to ensuring stringent and sound management of public finances, they cannot take on the financing of this European scheme as well.

intervention.name: Ioan ENCIU
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the motion for a European Parliament resolution on eCall: a new 112 service for citizens, because it will greatly improve the effectiveness of emergency services on our roads.

eCall represents an innovative and technologically advanced tool to promptly notify car accidents through satellite technology. This own-initiative report, by stressing its countless benefits, clearly explains the European added value of the service, urging therefore the Commission to submit a proposal within the framework of Directive 2007/46/EC in order to ensure the deployment of a public, 112-based eCall system by 2015 in all new, type-approved cars and in all Member States.

I fully share the opinion that the service must be simple, affordable, operational and accessible to everybody throughout the EU, regardless of the vehicle and its location and, imperatively, free of charge and obligatory.
The report also adequately stresses the need for data protection standards, in order to prevent the system from being used as a tool for tracing the journey of a vehicle.

intervention.name: Edite ESTRELA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for the report on ‘eCall: a new 112 service for citizens’, as I am in favour of introducing an accessible and reliable emergency call system which can work in an integrated way throughout Europe, enabling a significant reduction in the number of fatalities and injuries on Europe’s roads.

intervention.name: Diogo FEIO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: In Portugal, we have a proverb along the lines that it is better to lose a minute of your life than to lose your life in a minute; I presume that other countries have similar sayings. However, this calm and prudent advice is often overridden by the need to act quickly, particularly in emergency situations. In such cases, a minute can make all the difference between life and death. The eCall service seeks to address that need with regard to road accidents. At a time when mobile phones are widespread, it is incomprehensible that studies are not being carried out or assistance-alert solutions being applied that take the existence of mobile technology into account and take advantage of its full potential. The automatic nature of the service’s activation raises some doubts in my mind as to the privacy of the occupants of vehicles and the traceability of their journeys. However, these doubts do not detract from my overall favourable view of this initiative, nor my desire that its application will actually help to save lives. Unfortunately, my country has a high rate of road accidents. I hope that eCall will reduce this scourge.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: The active and passive safety of motorists has improved significantly over recent decades, with safety belts, airbags, energy-absorbing crumple zones, sensors, lights, and other such features. Everything that can be done to safeguard human life should be done. This report by Mr Koch and Ms Sehnalová concerns the regulation introducing the eCall service. The aim of this measure is to save human lives, and it makes installing an alert system in motor vehicles obligatory. In the event of an accident, and similar to what already happens in certain high-end vehicles, this system triggers an emergency call and transmits the coordinates of the damaged vehicle’s location. How many people might survive if they were attended to at the time of the accident? How many people have been trapped, often in inhospitable and/or undisclosed places, bleeding and unable to ask for help? I voted for this report, as I believe that eCall will be of benefit, and will allow many lives and many resources to be saved from 2015. As such, it should be seen as a public service accessible to all.

intervention.name: João FERREIRA
intervention.p: In the event of a road accident, it is vital that medical assistance arrives as early as possible at the accident scene, and it is also important that this assistance provides an adequate and effective response to the range of situations that may require its presence. The service proposed here, called eCall, is a system whose installation is to be made mandatory in all vehicles. In the event of an accident, it triggers an automatic call to the nearest emergency point, with information about the time and exact location of the accident, and the direction in which the vehicle was travelling. During this call, the emergency service operator will be able to speak and hear what is happening inside the vehicle. This technology enables access to a range of geographical data about location and direction, which are collated and monitored in real time via satellite. Notwithstanding other details about possible limitations of the system, this last aspect of access to data requires that we ensure a high level of protection for personal data and an assurance that all aspects of individual freedoms will be safeguarded. Unfortunately, the report does not provide an adequate response to those requirements.

intervention.name: Carlo FIDANZA
intervention.p: Parliament’s adoption of the report recommending deployment of the eCall system is a clear signal of its support for the topic of road safety. Every year in Europe, there are more than 40 000 fatalities on the roads. By means of the eCall system, it is anticipated that this number could be reduced by more than 2 500, with a reduction of 10-15% in the number of injured, thanks to an increase of 40-50% in the speed and efficiency of response centres. Furthermore, it is important to remember that eCall will have minimal economic repercussions on final costs, which amount to about EUR 100 per vehicle – a perfectly reasonable price given the great benefits it will bring. It is now essential that the Member States and the respective mobile phone networks commit themselves to improving their infrastructure so as to guarantee this service to the maximum extent possible. As of now, 5 500 drivers have use of such a service in 10 countries: the positive effects achievable from 2015 with its introduction in all 27 Member States would be of vital importance.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: More than 40 000 people die every year in road accidents. 150 000 people suffer an injury that results in permanent disability. According to predictions made by the World Bank and the World Health Organisation, the number of traffic accident victims is expected to rise in every area of the world and, by 2020, it will be the third most common cause of death. These predictions are alarming. In the face of such adverse developments, the EU cannot just stand idly by. This is why I am in favour of the introduction of the pan-European eCall system. Indeed, according to official statistical data on eCall, it is estimated that the full integration of the system in cars in EU Member States will save up to 2 500 lives annually, while also reducing the severity of injuries by 10-15%. This will be due to the more rapid arrival of the emergency services at the scene of the accident. eCall will reduce the time spent in traffic congestion and will contribute to the efficiency of road transport in the EU. The service will also allow the support of many other commercial services enhancing safety and economic benefits.

At the same time, it no less important to ensure that the system is in full compliance with the relevant regulations on data protection and privacy. Also, if the service is to fulfil its purpose, namely, to reduce the number of deaths and mitigate the severity of injuries in traffic accidents, it must always be free of charge and for the benefit of all drivers, irrespective of the make of vehicle.

intervention.name: Jacqueline FOSTER
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: While eCall could be a beneficial and welcome demonstration of how smart technology can be used in vehicles to potentially save lives following an accident on any European road, there are many flaws in this report that have still not been adequately addressed. This system should be voluntary. European citizens who purchase a car should be given the choice to pay for this technology to be fitted along with the optional extras which are already offered by vehicle manufacturers. A mandatory introduction would mean increased vehicle costs for citizens who may not want this device fitted. There is also an issue regarding the infrastructure and the high levels of investment needed to ensure full coverage across the EU. There are still huge signal black spots at cross border areas and areas with low population density where this system is promoted as being most needed. There have been no answers forthcoming regarding these costs. These points must be addressed before the Commission considers bringing forward a legislative proposal on the introduction of eCall to new vehicles with a mandatory implementation date of January 2015.

intervention.name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: I welcome the adoption of this resolution, which calls for the eCall system to be installed in all new cars by 2015. This is an important step forward for road safety as, were this technology to be introduced, it could enable a great number of lives to be saved on European roads. It is now up to the European Commission to come back to us with a legislative proposal. We in the European Parliament have expressed our view in the clearest possible manner.

intervention.name: Mathieu GROSCH
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Road safety is one of the cornerstones of European transport policy. The in-vehicle eCall system can make an important contribution to reducing the number of victims of road accidents.

The system automatically notifies the emergency services in the event that the vehicle is involved in a serious accident. I strongly support eCall because it cannot only save lives, but also reduce the severity of the injuries of those involved in accidents by providing immediate aid.

Particularly when EU citizens travel to another country, they often do not know exactly where they are and do not always speak the language. Therefore, the automatic eCall signal is especially useful, because the rescue services receive the information about the exact location of the vehicle immediately.

eCall should be interoperable and EU-wide. If every country has its own system which can only communicate with vehicles from that country, then we will not be able to exploit the potential of eCall to the full.

intervention.name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) - Vice
intervention.p: I hope that this technology will be implemented quickly in order to save lives. The ‘eCall’ system, which is the result of research financed by the European Union, is a small device based on the use of in-vehicle sensors. In the event of a serious accident, this device automatically dials the European emergency number, 112. The vehicle’s location and direction and the time of the accident are transmitted directly to the public safety answering point. Member States must then be allowed to choose how they organise the routing of calls, for example, either via the intermediary of a sorting platform, which distinguishes emergency calls requiring public service from those requiring assistance to be met by a private service provider. A pan-EU eCall service would enable emergency services to save time: 40% in urban areas and 50% in rural areas, according to the European Commission. While 30 900 deaths and over 1.5 million injured persons were recorded on EU roads in 2010 and 2009 respectively, eCall would reduce the number of deaths by at least 4% and severe injuries by at least 6%.

intervention.name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report, which urges the general introduction of the eCall in-vehicle emergency call system in the Member States. This public device automatically contacts the emergency services in the event of serious accidents, reducing the death toll, the severity of injuries and the number of secondary accidents. We have been supporting this idea since 2003, but it has been hampered by the manufacturers’ lobby, as they wanted to develop an optional, private system. What we have here is a truly public European system, a major advance in road safety that now only requires a legislative proposal from the Commission.

intervention.name: Brice HORTEFEUX
intervention.p: On Tuesday, 3 July, Parliament voted by a large majority for the development of the eCall technology, which will be fitted to all new vehicles by 2015. Using in-vehicle sensors, in case of a serious accident, the eCall system automatically alerts the nearest emergency service via the 112 call platform. eCall will provide key information to speed up the intervention of the mobile emergency services, such as the time, accurate location and information about the vehicle. eCall can also be activated manually, for example, in case of a heart attack. This free system will not be permanently operational. There will, therefore, be no risk of violation of personal data or of monitoring of movements. Thanks to this new device, over 2 500 lives could be saved each year and the emergency services will intervene more rapidly. Whilst it will be several years before this system is fully operational, in my opinion, this is a practical initiative that responds directly to citizens’ concerns.

intervention.name: Anna IBRISAGIC
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: We Swedish Conservatives voted against the own-initiative report on eCall today. The purpose of eCall is to make it easier, via computerisation, for the emergency services to get to the scene of an accident quickly. The intention is for it to be possible to trace vehicles that are involved in road traffic accidents. If an accident happens, it will be indicated at the nearest public safety answering point, wherever you happen to be in Europe. However, this service already exists on the market. Several car manufacturers already make cars with this service included. We therefore believe that the EU does not need to take a decision on this. Installation of eCall would involve increased costs for motorists, as cars would be more expensive to manufacture. It should be up to individual motorists to choose for themselves whether they want this service in their cars and therefore to pay for a more expensive car. From a privacy perspective, this also means that motorists can be monitored. If someone chooses this system as a consumer, it is a voluntary contract between the customer and the company. However, if it is decided upon by the EU, then it forces monitoring on people, which is something that we Swedish Conservatives did not feel able to support.

intervention.name: Juozas IMBRASAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this resolution because the aim of the in-vehicle eCall system is to ensure the automatic notification of the emergency services in the event of a serious accident, with the purpose of reducing road fatalities and alleviating the severity of road injuries by the earlier arrival of qualified and equipped assistance (the ‘golden hour’ principle). Based on data in the European Union for 2004, more than 40 000 people die every year in accidents and 150 000 people suffer permanent disability. eCall does not prevent accidents, but would improve the effectiveness of emergency services. When emergency services are promptly notified and know the accident location, they can arrive quickly and reduce the risk of death and the severity of injuries. It should be noted that numerous studies and projects based on scientific methodology underscore the positive safety effects of eCall. The eCall service should be free of charge and its installation in all new vehicles should be obligatory. The public eCall service should be simple, affordable, operational and accessible to everybody throughout the EU, regardless of the vehicle and its location.

intervention.name: Peter JAHR
intervention.p: I am also pleased that we have spoken out in favour of the mandatory introduction of the electronic eCall emergency system. If it will be possible to save an estimated 2 500 lives per year and reduce the number of serious injuries, then this must be a good system. However, as always, it is important to evaluate the practicability of the plan. Is it really possible for the system only to be activated in the event of a serious accident? What constitutes a serious accident? Is the car drivers’ data really secure? And, most importantly, what will the mandatory introduction of the emergency call system cost? I would ask everyone to think carefully about these and any other questions that arise. I would also like to emphasise once again how much I welcome this system, particularly as I cover long distances every week in my car.

intervention.name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Today, I endorsed the report calling for the introduction of legislation requiring vehicle manufacturers to install the eCall system in new vehicles from 2015 onwards. I think this is a legitimate requirement, because reducing the time needed for medical assistance to reach the victims of road accidents is extremely important and will help save the lives of many Europeans, Poles and people from my own city of Opole.

intervention.name: Philippe JUVIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The eCall system, the result of a European initiative, will allow rapid assistance to be provided to citizens who suffer road accidents on the territory of the European Union. This project aims to install a device in all vehicles that automatically calls 112 in case of a serious road accident or activation of the airbag. This new device will allow 2 500 lives to be saved each year and considerably reduce the number of injuries. At a time when the new technologies are proving to be a major factor in improving road safety, I voted in favour of this report.

intervention.name: Michał Tomasz KAMIŃSKI
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: The benefits of eCall are mostly demonstrated to be the reduction of the medical consequences of a crash, the reduced risk of a further accident on the scene and the reduced impact of an accident on the traffic. The ‘golden hour’ principle means that when emergency services are promptly notified and know the accident location, they can arrive quickly and reduce the risk of death and the severity of injuries.

For the system to work, we are going to need cooperation between vehicle manufacturers, mobile network operators and the Member States. The Member States will have to improve their system of public safety answering points so as to be able to handle eCalls. We should not forget that this is going to involve considerable expense.

Another important aspect of the system which needs to be worked out carefully is the protection of personal data. We are right to stress that the eCall system must not, under any circumstances, allow the journey of a vehicle to be traced, by which we mean that it must remain a dormant system until an emergency call is triggered. The eCall service cannot be used in any way to monitor and study a person’s movements or determine his location unless that person has been involved in an accident. I endorsed this report.

intervention.name: Sergej KOZLÍK
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: In the event of a severe road accident, an eCall-equipped vehicle will automatically trigger an emergency call and send an emergency message including key information about the accident, such as time, accurate location, direction of travel and vehicle description. This will enhance the effectiveness of the emergency services. For the deployment of the system, vehicle manufacturers need to include an onboard system capable of triggering eCall and mobile network operators should enable the transmission of eCalls and Member States should upgrade their public safety answering points. In 2011, the Commission adopted a recommendation calling for the required measures for the implementation of the eCall system by 2014 at the latest The EP requests that a delegated act be adopted by the end of 2012 in the form of a directive which will lay down binding specifications. I support the position of the EP.

intervention.name: Constance LE GRIP
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the own-initiative report presented by Olga Sehnalová and Dieter-Lebrecht Koch on eCall: a new ‘112’ service for citizens, which will soon have been in development for 10 years. With the aim of improved protection for Europe’s citizens, eCall is a new Europe-wide in-vehicle alarm system that automatically alerts the emergency services in the event of a serious accident, sending the GPS position of the accident location. Overall, 2 500 lives could be saved each year in Europe. I welcome Parliament’s vote in favour of this system, which strengthens the EU’s role in the protection of its citizens.

intervention.name: Petru Constantin LUHAN
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Although the introduction of such a service has been under discussion for a very long time, the fact that making this decision at EU level has been delayed until now is a positive factor because it gives Member States time to update the equipment required in the public safety answering points (PSAPs) which, when the service is launched, must operate with state of the art technology in every Member State. However, I would like to highlight in the report the aspect about the protection of personal data, which is fairly vague and must be carefully revised and supplemented before this public service is implemented so that it is absolutely clear to stakeholders about using citizens’ confidential data for other purposes, such as car manufacturers launching commercial activities.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for this report. In the event of a severe road accident, an eCall-equipped vehicle will automatically trigger an emergency call. Even if the passengers cannot speak, eCall creates a voice link to the closest public safety answering point (PSAP) and sends an emergency message, known as the minimum set of data (MSD), including key information about the accident, such as time, precise location, driving direction (resulting from accurate satellite-based data) and vehicle description. eCall can also be activated manually.

intervention.name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: A system for emergency calls from vehicles, as set out in the submitted report, may help to make the operations required for the rapid dispatch of the necessary assistance to an accident site significantly more effective. The emergency services will be quickly informed of transport accidents, even when the injured are unable to communicate. According to the information available to me, the system functionality pilot projects run in the Czech Republic showed that it was realistic to put this idea into practice. Not only as a doctor, but also as an individual, I am pleased about the possibility of implementing this emergency system that will lead to a greater chance of saving human lives.

intervention.name: Barbara MATERA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the obligatory introduction of the in-vehicle eCall 112 emergency call system in new European road vehicles sold from 2014 onwards. This new device is an emergency system that automatically transmits an emergency call to the nearest public safety answering point as soon as a serious accident takes place, giving key information such as the place and time of the accident, thereby enabling the rescue services to respond more rapidly. My vote in favour is based on the importance of the innovation of having an automatic emergency service that can reduce the risk of death and serious injury, thereby increasing European citizens’ safety on the Union’s roads.

intervention.name: Véronique MATHIEU HOUILLON
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this resolution to fit all vehicles offered for sale in the European Union with eCall technology from 2015. Thanks to this Europe-wide system, we could save 2 500 lives a year and reduce the number of severe injuries arising from traffic accidents.

intervention.name: Alexander MIRSKY
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: This is a very important resolution because in the event of a severe road accident, an eCall-equipped vehicle will automatically trigger an emergency call. All road users will benefit from that kind of equipment. I am in favour.

intervention.name: Andreas MÖLZER
intervention.p: The fundamental idea of an emergency service that calls the nearest public safety answering point automatically is a good one, but, as is so often the case, there are gaps in the idea which need to be closed before the system can be regarded as perfect. We live in an age when we can and must expect the highest standards in technological terms. I am of the opinion that every Member State should decide for itself whether it wants to fit this system in cars, because it involves certain risks. It is important to remember that there is a risk that the system will be activated in the case of every accident, even if it is ‘just’ a rear-end collision. When it makes a call, the emergency services will arrive and find out that there is ‘only’ damage to the vehicles and this may prevent them from reaching the scene of another accident in good time. We need to bear this in mind. Furthermore, the system should officially only be activated when it is needed, but it is difficult to establish this in advance. There is a risk of it being misused, even in stand-by mode. I see this as a breach of privacy, because the eCall system can be used to identify where people are and how fast they are driving, for example. For the reasons I have given, certain issues need to be rectified or reconsidered, which is why I have abstained.

intervention.name: Claudio MORGANTI
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: Every year in the European Union, road accidents give rise to about 40 000 fatalities, and more than 150 000 people suffer permanent disability as a result. These shocking statistics show us how dramatic the situation is and how important it therefore is to find ways of improving it. The report that we adopted today, and which I willingly supported, provides for the introduction of an automatic alarm system: when installed in a vehicle that has been involved in an accident, eCall will, in fact, send an alert concerning the event by making an encoded emergency call to the 112 number, which has now become the single European number for emergencies, valid, that is, in all Member States. Clearly, this will not help to prevent accidents, but it will certainly help rescue teams, for whom rapid and timely reaction is essential, to become more effective. Estimates indicate that it may be possible to save 2 500 human lives every year by means of this system. I hope that there will be many more than this, but in any case, every person that can be saved as a result of this system will nevertheless be a great success and an important result for everyone.

intervention.name: Radvilė MORKŪNAITĖ-MIKULĖNIENĖ
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour. It is my view that from 2015, eCall should be installed in all new models of cars and light vehicles and should function fully throughout the EU, as well as in other European countries wishing to use it. In Lithuania alone, there are more than 6 000 car accidents each year, in which more than 8 000 people are injured and almost 700 killed. The introduction from 2015 of the eCall system in all cars in EU Member States would save 2 500 lives a year, while reducing the severity of injuries by 10-15%. The introduction of the eCall system in a new car would cost less than EUR 100, but the driver should not have to shoulder the financial burden and the eCall service must be free of charge. The system does not send any signals and is completely dormant until sensors detect that a serious accident has taken place and automatically transmit a signal, even if, following the accident, the driver or passenger is unconscious. It will also be possible for a person who has witnessed the accident to activate the system by pressing a button. Research shows that when this technology is applied, rescuers arrive 40% quicker in urban areas and 50% quicker in rural areas. It is regrettable that over the course of more than five years, the voluntary deployment of this system has not produced any results.

intervention.name: Katarína NEVEĎALOVÁ
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: More than 39 000 lives are lost and more than 1.2 million passengers are injured every year in road accidents across the EU. These alarming statistics point to the fact that road safety concerns all EU citizens. Our task is therefore to support proposals that would reduce the death rate in road accidents and would constitute a step forward in ensuring road safety. The eCall system is a modern, intelligent traffic safety system, the role of which is to automatically call the emergency services in the event of an accident without the driver, who may be injured or unconscious, having to lift a finger. The speedy and timely intervention of the emergency services is often crucial. In the case of serious injuries, every minute counts. The eCall system represents a major challenge for the transport policies of the EU Member States. In view of the time that the EU has spent since 2003 trying to develop a system in detail, it is high time for it to be finally harmonised across all Member States. The only downside may be the slightly higher costs when purchasing a vehicle, but one must realise that in mass production, it would be a marginal amount which is negligible compared to the number of lives saved.

intervention.name: Rolandas PAKSAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group
intervention.p: I welcome this resolution. eCall is a vitally important system. In order to improve citizens’ living conditions and even save their lives, the emergency call system should be constantly expanded and improved. The full integration of this system would save thousands of lives each year. It is very important for the system to be used in heavy goods vehicles, as well as agricultural and industrial vehicles. Such vehicles are used in remote and isolated areas and drivers are sometimes unable to contact the emergency services in the event of an accident.

intervention.name: Justas Vincas PALECKIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report in order to strengthen the protection of European citizens.

The EU does so much for free movement within the Member States, and we have to make this movement safe. I regret that many Member States have not yet joined the eCall system. It is a joint project and all European citizens have the right to the same level of protection, regardless of their nationality. The improvement in the response of the European emergency services will permit up to 2 500 lives to be saved annually and to reduce the severity of injuries by 10-15%.

Therefore, I support the rapporteur, who calls on the Commission to make legally binding decisions on that issue. I join the colleagues who are concerned about respect for the privacy of the people who have the eCall system installed. The system should not be allowed to track the movement of cars. Only information on the exact place of the accident is necessary for intervention in case of emergency.

intervention.name: Georgios PAPANIKOLAOU
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: This particular report, which I supported, sets out practical applications and actions to reduce the number of road accident victims, in order to provide European citizens with better protection. For Greece, progress in efforts to use technology to identify and quickly rescue road accident victims has added value, given that Greece – together with Romania – recently broke the record for road accident victims (approximately 130 per million per annum). However, the 112 service has an exponential practical value when an accident occurs in an isolated, provincial location, where it is hard for victims to inform anyone of their location and situation.

intervention.name: Maria do Céu PATRÃO NEVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: eCall is a mechanism to trigger automatically an emergency call in the event of a severe road accident. I voted for this report, as the economic benefits of this system and its positive impact on the sector have been studied, and because I believe the greatest benefit of the eCall system will be to reduce the number of fatalities and the severity of injuries caused by road accidents, since the emergency services will arrive at the scene of the accident faster.

intervention.name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
intervention.p: The motion helps to improve the effectiveness of the emergency services by creating a voice connection with the nearest public safety answering point (PSAP) and sending an emergency message. The Commission decided in 2011 that it would take legislative action to make the introduction of eCall obligatory. In the hope that the number of road victims will decrease thanks to the swifter arrival of the emergency services at the scene of the accident, I am voting in favour of the motion.

intervention.name: Paulo RANGEL
intervention.p: eCall is a European initiative, the main aim of which is to provide rapid assistance to motorists involved in road accidents across the EU. The implementation of the project involves installing a device in all vehicles which automatically calls 112 in the event of a road accident and transmits the coordinates to the competent authorities via GPS. eCall does not prevent accidents, but it does make the emergency services more effective. When the emergency services are promptly notified and know the accident location, they can arrive quickly and reduce the risk of death and the severity of injuries. I would stress that any added in-vehicle application based on the eCall telematics platform should comply fully with the relevant data protection and privacy regulations. I voted for this report for those reasons.

intervention.name: Crescenzio RIVELLINI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Today, during the part-session in Strasbourg, we voted on the report by Mr Koch and Ms Sehnalová. Parliament has come out clearly in support of all motorists in Europe, so that they can benefit from a free emergency call system. Given that the voluntary approach has failed to produce results, the Commission is being urged to put forward legislative measures as soon as possible to ensure that the eCall system becomes obligatory in all EU countries by 2015. In the resolution, the Commission is invited to consider the possibility of extending the system in the near future to other vehicles, such as motorcycles, buses, coaches and lorries. This system uses the technology of 112 emergency calls so as to automatically alert the emergency services of the location of the vehicle in the event of a serious accident, thereby saving lives, reducing the severity of injuries and also ensuring the arrival of qualified and fully equipped paramedics within an hour of the accident, under what is known as the ‘golden hour principle’. The eCall system will enable around 2 500 lives to be saved every year. It is also considered that the public eCall service should be obligatory and available free of charge to all drivers in Europe, regardless of the type of vehicle.

intervention.name: Robert ROCHEFORT
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: The aim of the in-vehicle eCall system is to ensure the automatic notification of the emergency services in case of a serious accident, allowing the emergency services to arrive faster at the scene and thus reduce the number of road fatalities and the severity of injuries. In Europe, over 40 000 people die each year in road accidents and 150 000 people suffer permanent disability. The installation of the eCall system in all vehicles in the Union would save the lives of 2 500 people each year and reduce the severity of injuries by 10-15%. This system must therefore be installed as soon as possible in Europe’s vehicles. In this resolution, Parliament calls for all new cars to be fitted with this device by 2015 and insists on the fact that this emergency call service should be free of charge and accessible to everyone. The resolution also provides guarantees on the use of the data, stressing that the eCall service cannot be used to monitor a person’s movements or determine his location unless that person has been involved in an accident. It has my support.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: Abstention. On the one hand, eCall could contribute to improving emergency services in certain cases. On the other hand, the Commission has so far refused to propose efficient measures on accident avoidance, such as stricter speed and alcohol limits. The Greens/EFA asked for more detailed information on the eCall infrastructure costs and who would pay them. We also asked for better measures on interference with eCall in terms of false or imprecise information in case of an accident. The answers were unsatisfactory and our amendments on these items were rejected.

intervention.name: Licia RONZULLI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this document because I believe the proposal to equip all new vehicles with the eCall device by 2015 to be important. It will enable the rescue services to be alerted automatically in the event of a road accident by means of the public 112 emergency call service. In this way, it would be possible for the emergency services to arrive more rapidly; something that could save around 2 500 lives per year and also significantly reduce the severity of injuries sustained.

intervention.name: Nikolaos SALAVRAKOS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report as, in the event of a severe road accident, an eCall-equipped vehicle will automatically trigger an emergency call. I believe that it proposes positive measures for the reduction of the number of fatalities and the mitigation of the severity of injuries caused by road accidents.

intervention.name: Matteo SALVINI
intervention.p: I voted firmly for this report. European car manufacturers claim they are ready to take on the challenge of incorporating this type of equipment in the vehicles they produce. This will have the result of saving human lives. However, I should not like the European Parliament to go too far, perhaps by proposing to extend eCall to other types of vehicle too rapidly. In current circumstances, that would amount to excessive costs for manufacturers and would probably not have the effect of improving road safety. As regards ordinary cars, I remain in favour, and I hope that these devices will soon be launched on the market.

intervention.name: Amalia SARTORI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Road safety is a subject of enormous importance, especially nowadays, when technology and developments in the automotive sector are reaching ever higher levels. The EU’s task is to adopt legislation that will enable citizens to travel on safe roads and in safe vehicles. That is why I voted for the resolution moved by Mr Koch and Ms Sehnalová on the adoption of the eCall system in all cars by 2015. The introduction of this device will bring many benefits. In the event of a serious accident, a vehicle equipped with eCall will automatically place a 112 emergency call, even if the passenger is not in a fit state to speak, and provide the emergency services with all the key information on the accident. Thanks to the use of this technology, about 2 500 lives will be saved every year and the severity of injuries sustained will fall by 10-15%, all due to the swifter and more efficient intervention of the rescue services at the scene of the accident.

intervention.name: Vilja SAVISAAR-TOOMAST
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: The objective of eCall is to ensure the automatic notification of emergency services from inside a vehicle in the case of an accident, in order to reduce the number of casualties from traffic accidents and mitigate the seriousness of injuries sustained in traffic accidents. eCall will speed up the arrival of qualified and properly equipped assistance. The application of eCall technology must be compulsory and available to all drivers of vehicles in the European Union. It is also important that vehicles imported into Europe from third countries should be required to have eCall technology. eCall technology must be installed in all new cars. eCall technology is based on the 112 emergency number, and must be compulsory and free of charge for all. Parliament is calling on the European Commission to acknowledge the need to develop, by the end of 2012, a directive that would include the implementation of eCall. In order to mitigate the problems associated with the introduction of eCall, the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection have called upon Member States to cooperate with the European Commission to plan and implement national pilot programmes for the utilisation of the European in-car automatic emergency call system (eCall), in order to address all of the problems that may arise.

The infrastructure required for the eCall technology must also be created, and telephone operators must be provided with the training required to prepare them for the compulsory introduction of this system in all Member States by 2015. Based on the above, I supported the adoption of this report.

intervention.name: Debora SERRACCHIANI
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the Sehnalová report on the establishment of the security system known as eCall, as I believe it is an excellent means of preventing road accidents and more. Thanks to this system, it will also be possible from now on to reduce the congestion caused by accidents, thus preventing more accidents from occurring. I regret the delays and the lack of progress in the voluntary deployment of eCall to date and I hope that all parties involved will act simultaneously in order to establish this service. I also believe there must be coordinated awareness-raising campaigns concerning the eCall system and its benefits for European citizens, with the aim of increasing both the understanding of, and the demand for, the service.

intervention.name: Sergio Paolo Francesco SILVESTRIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Since, according to the prediction made by the World Bank, the number of traffic accident victims is expected to rise in every area of the world, the European Union must face up to the problem. Currently, in Europe, based on 2004 data, more than 40 000 people die every year in road accidents and 150 000 suffer permanent disability. This vote will encourage the deployment of eCall; in the event of a severe accident, a vehicle equipped with this device will automatically trigger an emergency call. Even if the passenger cannot speak, eCall creates a voice link to the nearest public safety answering point and sends an emergency message, including key information about the accident, such as time, accurate location, driving direction (resulting from accurate satellite-based data) and vehicle description.

intervention.name: Marc TARABELLA
intervention.p: This vote in favour was a straightforward matter. In 2015, we wish to see all new cars sold in Europe fitted with this device. It will activate automatically in case of accident, even if the driver is unconscious. It could also be activated manually This device could prove to be very valuable, especially in rural areas. According to the figures, 2 500 lives could be saved each year. The French group PSA has already jumped on the bandwagon.

intervention.name: Nuno TEIXEIRA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The eCall system seeks to improve assistance in the event of an accident, as it triggers an automatic call to the respective emergency services, with information about the time of the accident and the exact location, description and driving direction of the vehicle involved. eCall can therefore reduce the number of fatalities and the severity of injuries. This service, which has already been introduced by the Commission on a voluntary basis, will now be made obligatory for all vehicles from 2015. The Member States are therefore called on to define which infrastructure will receive the emergency calls, and mobile network operators are called on to incorporate this system into their networks, so that the calls will be a free public service using the 112 number. Moreover, it must be interoperable with existing private systems and data sharing must be restricted to what is necessary for this specific purpose. I support this report because I believe it benefits the European public, and also because it opens up new opportunities for the motor vehicle industry, as it can be used for new applications and services.

intervention.name: Silvia-Adriana ȚICĂU
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for the report on eCall: a new 112 service for citizens, because it is estimated that the full integration of the system in cars in the EU will save roughly 2 500 lives annually. The aim of the in-vehicle eCall system is to ensure the automatic notification of the emergency services in the case of a serious accident, with the purpose of reducing road fatalities and alleviating the severity of road accident injuries through the faster arrival of qualified and equipped assistance. The emergency call is generated automatically via the activation of in-vehicle sensors which, when activated, establish a voice and data connection directly with the public safety answering points. We should highlight agricultural and industrial vehicles, particularly agricultural tractors, which operate in remote and isolated areas, and are therefore often unable to notify the emergency services in the event of an accident. I voted for the paragraph which calls on the Commission to consider whether the eCall system needs to be extended in the near future to include other vehicles, such as heavy goods vehicles, buses, coaches and powered two-wheelers, and to assess whether it also needs to be introduced for agricultural tractors and industrial vehicles.

intervention.name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: It is said that with the eCall system, 2 500 lives will be saved annually in the EU and severe injuries will be reduced by 10-15%. With this service, we can avoid the suffering of 2 500 families every year.

Although I note that there are several doubts about eCall, such as coordination, data protection, public and private added value services, possible false alarms generated by eCalls, etc., I can only see the positive points of it, namely, that it ensures automatic notification, faster arrival of emergency teams and that the call is made without encountering any language barrier in any EU country.
I will support this report because any measure taken that helps to save lives is a very positive action.

intervention.name: Derek VAUGHAN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I support calls for a free-of-charge emergency eCall system, which would alert rescue services to road crashes automatically. Such a system could help save lives and reduce injuries following serious road accidents. An in-vehicle eCall system would automatically alert emergency services to the location of accidents, which will enable victims to be treated by professionals as quickly and efficiently as possible. I believe that this system should be made available to all motorists across the EU. If introduced, we could see 2 500 fewer deaths a year and the severity of injuries would also be reduced. I now hope that the Commission will respond to calls from MEPs and come forward with some binding legislation on this issue.

intervention.name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: Road accidents are still one of the major causes of death and injury, not only in the European Union but throughout the world, and this at a time when technological developments are able to guarantee leading-edge, quality services in the fields of road safety and immediate intervention. This is the case with eCall, a system that sends emergency calls to answering point operators which will allow rapid assistance in case of accidents and which is closely linked with 112, the European emergency number.

I welcome the attention the text pays to the free and universally accessible nature of the eCall system as a public service, whilst taking into account the various categories of vehicles and the needs of drivers, including disabled drivers, as well as the importance it attaches to data protection and the privacy of the beneficiaries, with their prior agreement.

intervention.name: Oldřich VLASÁK
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: I abstained from the report, although my own country is one of the pioneers of this solution. Although reducing road accidents and saving lives is a priority for me, it is obvious that nothing comes for free in this world, and somebody always has to pick up the bill. The proposal in Articles 9 and 39 for eCall to be free of charge is therefore problematic, as it suggests that, in the case of new vehicles, calls would be payment-free – where there is no problem because they are free already – and so would the equipment. In view of the fact that someone will have to pay for it, we will see either a further assault on public finances or higher prices for vehicles, if the burden is transferred to car makers, who will pass it on. The issue of possible costs for the emergency services from false alarms is also rather problematic, a fact pointed out by the rapporteurs themselves. I therefore support the eCall service, but I would like a clear statement on who will pay and from what source.

intervention.name: Dominique VLASTO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Parliament has just laid the bases for the deployment of eCall, an innovative system that is able automatically to alert the emergency services within the EU in the event of a car accident. I wish to see technology neutrality. This is a prerequisite for an effective system capable of supporting innovation. Whilst some manufacturers have already adopted comparable systems, I see no value in our making them incompatible with eCall. Let us avoid a war amongst the lobbies to impose a system when so many lives are at stake. If eCall must be technology neutral, it must also be financially neutral. This innovation cannot be achieved to the detriment of the consumer. The system aims to be general and obligatory. In these circumstances, we cannot impose an unreasonable cost on future buyers. I also think it is essential to introduce the conditions for free and fair competition to avoid the appearance of unfair charges. I therefore supported this recommendation in order to introduce this innovative system in the best manner possible. The era of free movement has become a reality in Europe; safety must not stop at the borders. Europe must continue to be a leader in road safety matters.

intervention.name: Angelika WERTHMANN
intervention.p: The Commission decided in 2011 to adopt some legislative measures to introduce a binding eCall system, so it will be necessary to bring in a new regulation to ensure that all vehicles will be equipped with the right components to make an eCall possible. Today, Parliament is voting on a motion for a resolution which reflects its points of view and main guidelines to the Commission.

intervention.name: Janusz ZEMKE
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Better implementation of the eCall service across the European Union will improve road safety. Motor vehicles would be installed with a system which sends an alarm signal to the emergency services automatically, something which is extremely important when the victims of an accident have lost consciousness. If qualified and well-equipped assistance were able to reach accidents more quickly, we would be able to bring down Europe’s high number of accident fatalities.

In my opinion, however, something which must worry us is the lack of progress on voluntary implementation of this service in some Member States, just as we are seeing delays in the efficient functioning of the European emergency number 112, on which the eCall project we are talking about is to be based. It is imperative that the Commission, Parliament and the Council take action which will lead to the establishment of a public service of this kind throughout the EU, but on the understanding that it should be operational, affordable and accessible to all vehicle users.

It is also essential to adopt legislative measures to ensure that the establishment of an EU-wide eCall system will not, under any circumstances, infringe the civil rights of vehicle users, by being able to trace vehicle movements for example, or violate the guarantee to protect their personal data.

intervention.name: Luís Paulo ALVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Making investment in Europe more attractive requires the implementation of measures and reforms at both European and national level. To make investing and working in Europe more attractive, it is crucial to create a level playing field for companies. Developing the internal market has to be one of the EU’s main priorities for developing a favourable climate that encourages companies and consumers. This is particularly important in a globalised economy, where businesses have some flexibility in choosing where to operate. The regulatory environment needs to be further improved, to enable businesses in Europe to enhance their competitiveness and their ability to grow and create jobs.

intervention.name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this important resolution on attractiveness of investing in Europe, which was adopted at a very crucial time for Europe, during which attracting investments and ensuring a balanced investment base in European regions are necessary elements for growth and economic recovery. We, Members of the European Parliament, urgently ask for growth to create wealth and employment, to encourage the competitiveness of the Union globally, and to increase economic and regional convergence within the EU. I support the position of the rapporteur that our goal needs to be dual: firstly, Europe needs to remain the first investment destination at a global level – a position that is at stake given the strong global competition from new investment destinations; secondly, investments need to contribute to balanced growth and cohesion within the EU. We, Members of the European Parliament, call for a European, comprehensive and integrated strategy for investments, within the framework of the EU 2020 strategy, to enhance the EU’s effort to achieve higher growth rates and create jobs, particularly in countries that face weak growth or recession, as is the case in Greece.

intervention.name: Elena Oana ANTONESCU
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: At a time when the economic and financial crisis has had a direct impact on the standard of living of many European citizens, reinforcing the European Union’s position as a main global destination for foreign investment is vital for European countries’ economic recovery. It is imperative to adopt measures to help both make Europe’s workers and companies more competitive and make Member States’ economies more attractive to foreign investors.

Adopting these policies is the only solution for creating jobs and kick-starting economic growth. At international level, it is important for the European Union to retain its role in promoting and actively participating in the processes supporting global economic governance. I endorse and encourage the European Union’s policy of continuing its efforts to sign bilateral or multilateral agreements promoting free trade and the EU’s involvement in these trade arrangements.

intervention.name: Sophie AUCONIE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Another topic in this plenary sitting shows that the strategy for growth, jobs and the competitiveness of our companies is under way. It has not waited for the French socialists. I voted in favour of a text whose objective is to attract foreign investors to Europe. Even though Europe remains the main destination region for foreign direct investment, weak economic growth, high taxation and high public debt accumulation raise concerns to investors. We must ensure that businesses can compete openly and fairly, promote the entrepreneurial spirit amongst local entrepreneurs and fully exploit the Structural Funds. The growing difficulties faced by SMEs in accessing funding show us that there is a need to encourage investment in the real economy. As Parliament’s rapporteur on the motion for a resolution on the Social Business Initiative – creating a favourable climate for social enterprises, key stakeholders in the social economy and innovation, it is this form of support that I wish to provide to social enterprises. I also welcome the political agreement that was reached on my report last week, an agreement that was arrived at thanks especially to the constructive proposals put forward by the Commission and by Michel Barnier’s office.

intervention.name: Liam Aylward and Pat the Cope Gallagher
intervention.p: We fully endorse the report’s recommendations to the EU to address the Union’s weaknesses and strengthen its advantages, in order to attract and maximise global investment opportunities.

We fully support what it says about increasing the benefits of the cohesion policy, addressing human capital needs in the EU, and encouraging research and innovation. Our competitive corporate tax rate, however, is the cornerstone of Ireland’s attractiveness for foreign direct investment and global businesses.
Harmonisation of the corporate tax rate (CCCTB) would very adversely affect that strong element of the Irish economy which is essential for economic recovery and growth.

Taxation matters are a national competence and EU institutions must respect that. Under the additional protocol in relation to the concerns of the Irish people on the Treaty of Lisbon, which was recently ratified in the European Parliament, taxation matters are a competence of Member States.

In our opinion, the CCCTB would not improve the functioning of the single market but would adversely interfere with small open economies such as Ireland’s. For that reason, we abstained on this report.

intervention.name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report on reviewing the strategy for investment in Europe and supplementing it with new instruments. I believe that it is essential to exploit the EU’s advantage as the world’s largest single common market (including its high standard of living, high labour productivity, legal certainty and research and innovation capacity). I agree that as the level of unemployment increases and forecasts for Europe’s recovery remain pessimistic, new measures need to be taken to retain current investors and attract new ones. In order to tackle the challenges of the recession and slow economic growth, there is a need for more efficient tools and methods, new funding mechanisms and investment schemes. I agree that increasing investment in Europe, creating jobs within the EU and maintaining the EU’s international competitiveness must be a priority. It is important to achieve smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the EU by reducing regional disparities.

intervention.name: Regina BASTOS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: In a situation of incipient economic growth, market instability and increased global imbalances, the EU needs to strengthen its competitive advantages in order to attract investment, and thus promote balanced growth and greater cohesion. This report, for which I voted, calls on the Commission to draft a communication assessing and promoting the attractiveness of investing in Europe. This should include recommendations to the Member States and act as one of the bases for enhancing the EU investment environment. Despite being the world’s largest recipient of foreign direct investment, Europe needs to fix its weaknesses and make the most of its advantages and strengths, given increased competition from developing countries. Weak economic growth in Europe, high taxes and excessive public debt are factors which raise concerns among investors. However, the high quality and diversity of our human capital, the predictability of the business environment, and the high potential for research and innovation all work to our market’s advantage and are factors that should be strengthened and enhanced.

intervention.name: Sergio BERLATO
intervention.p: Europe is considered to be the largest regional destination for foreign direct investment. A quarter of the world’s total consumption and investment takes place within its borders. However, the weak economic growth Europe has recorded in these last years and the high public debt accumulation in Member States raise concerns to investors, which have been magnified in the face of global competition, especially from the emerging economies. There are two distinct aspects to consider when it comes to the attractiveness of investing in Europe – on the one hand, there is the need to make Europe an attractive destination for foreign investors and, on the other, the need to make entrepreneurship attractive for the local entrepreneur. Reforms are needed to attract investment to Europe, at both national and European levels, aimed at improving the functioning of the single European market. I therefore agree with the rapporteur’s request to the Commission to draw up a communication to evaluate as well as promote the attractiveness of investing in Europe, including policy recommendations to Member States targeted at enhancing the investment environment in the Union. In my opinion, furthermore, we need to improve the regulatory framework further so as to enable small and medium-sized enterprises to compete fairly, so that we can make Europe an attractive place in which to invest and work and enhance its ability to create wealth and jobs.

intervention.name: Mara BIZZOTTO
intervention.p: I am voting in favour of the Kratsa-Tsagaropoulou report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe. This report is intended to encourage changes in existing legislation in order to promote public and private investment, whether from within Europe or from third countries, for which the incentive is currently lacking, especially on account of the excessive tax burden. The aim is to establish a common policy directed at monetary, trade and budgetary stability, and to increase investment, notably in renewable energy, and, above all, in support of small and medium-sized enterprises, which represent the beating heart of European industry, especially Italian industry.

intervention.name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report because the economic, financial and fiscal crisis in the European Union has significantly broadened economic and social disparities among Member States and regions, resulting in an uneven distribution of inward and outward investment across the European Union. The global economy has embarked on the road to recovery, but there is limited room for manoeuvre, and ensuring a steady economic recovery process requires policies at international, EU and national level to be cautious. The European Union suffers from weak growth and expected growth rates differ significantly across the European Union. This weak growth is due to continued uncertainty and a lack of consumer and market confidence. The financing of the Member States’ public debt has the effect of absorbing resources for investment, growth and employment, while capital flight from certain Member States to certain other Member States, as well as to certain third countries, may contribute to a worsening of the EU balance of payments situation. In order to tackle the fiscal crisis and enhance growth and employment, the Union should further exploit its strengths, such as the high level of consumption, education and quality of life, its research and innovation capacity, high labour efficiency and productivity, as well as a friendly and motivational business environment. It is therefore necessary to establish a consistent framework of stability within monetary, fiscal and trade policy, in order to facilitate the flow of direct investment in all Member States and EU regions, thereby contributing to correcting the European Union’s macro-economic imbalances.

intervention.name: Philippe BOULLAND
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe. This report sets the European Union two objectives for reviving investment: making Europe an attractive destination again for foreign investors and promoting the entrepreneurial spirit amongst local entrepreneurs. These measures must allow us to counterbalance weak economic growth, high taxation and high public debt accumulation, which are raising major concerns to investors. I also support the recommendations the rapporteur makes in this document relating to the fields upon which we need to focus our energy and our action: we must address human capital needs better, ensure stability and improve access to finance, strengthen territorial cooperation, enhance the single market and boost research and innovation.

intervention.name: Alain CADEC
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe.
