This report especially underlines the need for stressing the attractiveness of the Structural Funds and of the single market to attract investors. I share the rapporteur’s vision of an integrated investment strategy within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy. It is a good thing to reinforce coordination in this area, given the difficult economic context confronting us in Europe. Our ability to remain attractive and competitive in an increasingly competitive world is at stake.

intervention.name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
intervention.p: Making investment in Europe more attractive requires the implementation of measures and reforms at both European and national level. To make investing and working in Europe more attractive, it is vital to create conditions whereby companies can enjoy a climate of fair and open competition. The internal market is one of the EU’s main priorities for developing a favourable climate that encourages companies and consumers. It is vital to promote the two ways of attracting investment: a) making Europe an attractive destination for foreign investors; and b) making the business environment attractive for local entrepreneurs. I therefore voted for this report, as I believe, inter alia , that it is essential to develop the EU’s human capital by modernising labour markets and the education systems of the Member States, and by promoting the mobility of students, researchers, professors and workers.

intervention.name: David CASA
intervention.p: In order to recover from the economic crisis and stimulate growth in the region, Europe needs to make itself more attractive for foreign direct investment. This can be achieved partially through fostering entrepreneurship, which requires reforming the regulatory environment to increase the competitiveness of European businesses and their ability to create jobs. I believe that the suggestions outlined in this report are compatible with such needs in terms of future investment and have therefore voted in favour of the resolution.

intervention.name: Carlos COELHO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The effects of the economic and financial crisis which has been plaguing the EU have contributed significantly to increasing economic and social disparities between Member States and regions, including a huge imbalance in the distribution of investment. Until recently, this area was dependent on bilateral treaties, with a large number of agreements, causing massive fragmentation and contributing to a lack of uniformity in the treatment of investors in the EU, and in their level of growth. As the Treaty of Lisbon has granted the EU exclusive competence in the field of foreign direct investment, it will be responsible for setting out an international investment policy that increases competitiveness and contributes to achieving the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

A comprehensive common policy on investment should be developed that can provide investors with greater legal certainty and a predictable and stable framework that is fair and properly regulated. It is important to make Europe a more attractive space for investing and working, creating the necessary conditions for businesses to enjoy a climate of open competition. This will have a significant effect in terms of increasing productivity, with a positive impact on growth and employment.

intervention.name: Emer COSTELLO
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe, which calls on the Commission to present a strategy on how to make investment, in particular, foreign direct investment, in Europe more attractive. I welcome the concern expressed about high youth unemployment figures and the measures proposed throughout the report to address this. In particular, the support for a youth guarantee scheme, which would ensure that every young person in Europe is offered a job, further education or work-focused training at the latest four months after leaving education or after becoming unemployed, is an important initiative to tackle youth unemployment. The calls for an increase in funding for mobility and development of knowledge, through the ‘Erasmus for All’ programme, are also welcomed as a tool towards both future investment and a reduction of youth unemployment.

intervention.name: Corina CREȚU
intervention.p: I voted for the resolution on increasing the attractiveness for investments. The EU needs to respond appropriately to the challenges of stabilising the international economy in order to fully exploit the global opportunities available. The EU has to address its weaknesses and enhance the advantages of all countries and regions to attract local and international investments which will contribute to its balanced growth and cohesion. The EU is the world’s largest trading bloc and external trade has so far played a dynamic role in boosting growth, especially in the services sector. At the same time, attracting investment needs to be distinguished at two levels: making Europe an attractive destination for foreign investors and making entrepreneurship attractive for local entrepreneurs. Reforms, both at national and European level, are necessary to improve the functioning of the single market and fully exploit the Structural Funds.

intervention.name: Rachida DATI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Europe has many instruments at its disposal to return to growth, boost market confidence and attract investments. It is high time for the Union to make full use of them. That is what this report reminds us of, and that is why I voted in its favour. I especially welcome the emphasis it lays on the development of the ‘Erasmus for Enterprises’, ‘Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs’ programmes and the ‘COSME’ competitiveness programme for SMEs. Europe has enormous opportunities to promote exchanges and intercultural dialogue amongst entrepreneurs, especially amongst the younger ones. These opportunities must be taken.

intervention.name: Christine DE VEYRAC
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this text, which encourages the national governments to make the reforms necessary to improve the business climate in the EU in order to attract foreign investment to our regions. The Member States have to make efforts to reassure investors, by controlling their budgets, by reforming corporate taxation and by improving access to credit and European aid for SMEs. As for European Union public funds, these must now be used, as a priority, for major projects that are essential to reviving our regions. The pursuit of and increase in investment must be a priority for all, for a rapid return to strong growth in the single market.

intervention.name: Edite ESTRELA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for the report on ‘the attractiveness of investing in Europe’, as it calls on the Commission to put forward a strategy to make foreign direct investment in Europe more attractive, in particular, by investing in cohesion policy, creating jobs for more young people, combating tax evasion, and facilitating the mobility of citizens and workers.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: The economic and financial crisis that Europe is experiencing, with restrictive public investment policies due to economic governance, has led to the bankruptcy of many companies and a sharp increase in unemployment, with the threat of social collapse. Despite the crisis, the EU continues to be the world’s main beneficiary of investment. However, some companies are relocating their factories to countries with lower taxes, less bureaucracy and cheaper labour. It is therefore urgent to reverse this situation by reducing bureaucracy and cutting taxes for our entrepreneurs, in order to prevent the commercial centre of the world from moving from Europe to the Pacific. It is also vital to make our companies more competitive by investing in innovation and technological development. I therefore welcome the presentation of this report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe, for which I voted. I also hope that it will contribute towards strengthening economic growth in the EU, as this is a region that values the security and quality of capital, has highly qualified professionals, has an excellent transport network, is committed to innovation and technological development, and ensures monetary and financial stability.

intervention.name: João FERREIRA
intervention.p: This report focuses on what it considers to be the need to develop the internal market, in order to develop ‘a friendly and motivational environment for businesses and consumers’ which is able to attract both national and international investment. In order for this investment to take place, the rapporteur argues that ‘the EU needs a coherent political, economic and regulatory framework’. The elements that make up this framework include promoting the establishment of new trade agreements with third countries; structural reforms in the Member States in order to ensure greater coordination between the policies of the EU; the modernisation of labour markets, through flexicurity; education and professional training to meet the needs of the single market; economic governance; and the Euro Plus Pact. In other words, it is an example of the savage neoliberal agenda that has driven the process of dismantling society’s progress that is under way in the EU, and the unprecedented aggression being inflicted on workers and the public. Naturally, we voted against.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: Instability in international financial markets is currently high. The huge debt levels and rising oil prices pose significant risks for the future. It is necessary and important to seek solutions to reduce these risks of negative development. Structural problems, insufficient global rebalancing, a persistent development gap, rising unemployment – these are all current problems to which we must respond appropriately and which we must urgently resolve in the spirit of cooperation and social solidarity.

Europe remains the largest regional destination for foreign direct investment (FDI). A quarter of the world’s total consumption and investment takes place within its expanding borders. Investors are attracted to the EU market mainly as a result of its high-quality and diverse human capital, its emphasis on corporate social responsibility, its relatively predictable business environment and its high potential in research and innovation. Despite these facts, we do not make full use of the EU’s potential, and high taxes disincentivise investors, as does the huge public debt. Meanwhile, global competition from emerging economies is growing steadily. In this context, the single internal EU market is of particular importance. This is one of our most important priorities. With its 500 million consumers, it offers tremendous advantages for investors; we must therefore continue to develop and support those regimes that facilitate and encourage investment in the EU. I am firmly convinced that especially during this crisis, we must promote our strengths more than ever before.

intervention.name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) - Vice
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report because, whatever the cost, if we wish to come out of the current economic crisis unscathed, we must succeed in attracting worldwide investors to the European Union. Europe remains the main destination region for foreign direct investment (FDI), but its share is falling. Weak economic growth, high taxation and debt raise concerns on the part of investors which can be magnified in the face of global competition, especially from emerging economies. The EU must address its weaknesses and exploit its competitive advantages. We must make Europe an attractive destination once more for foreign investors and promote entrepreneurial spirit amongst local entrepreneurs. To do so, the EU needs a coherent political, economic and regulatory framework based on sustainable growth objectives and the Community method. We must, for example, address human capital needs better (by focusing on education and training), ensure stability and improve access to finance (especially for SMEs), promote the use of public-private partnerships, boost research and innovation and enhance the single market. We need a coherent, realistic economic and business policy.

intervention.name: Juozas IMBRASAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this resolution on the attractiveness of investing in Europe because the economic, financial and fiscal crisis in the EU has significantly broadened economic and social disparities among Member States and regions, resulting in an uneven distribution of inward and outward investment across the EU. It is necessary to establish a consistent framework of stability within monetary, fiscal and trade policy in order to facilitate the flow of direct investment in all Member States and EU regions, thereby contributing to correcting the EU’s macro-economic imbalances. Today, we really need to mobilise EU policies to fully support growth, step up efforts to finance the economy through investment and strengthen job creation. Investors are attracted to the EU market mainly as a result of its high-quality and diverse human capital, its emphasis on corporate social responsibility, its relatively predictable business environment and its high potential in research and innovation. Nevertheless, Europe’s weak economic growth, high taxation and high public debt accumulation raise concerns on the part of investors which can be magnified in the face of global competition, especially from emerging economies, as well as the lack of opportunities to exploit the EU’s full potential. The Commission is therefore asked to prepare a communication to evaluate as well as promote the attractiveness of investing in Europe, including policy recommendations to Member States targeted at enhancing the EU investment environment. There is concern about the high youth unemployment figures in a number of Member States and negative employment prospects, particularly in Lithuania.

intervention.name: Philippe JUVIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The attractiveness of investing in the European Union is essential to the strategy for economic growth. The EU must retain its place as the top destination worldwide for foreign investment. It must, therefore, make investment a central component of all the flagship initiatives implemented within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy. To this end, Parliament is inviting the Commission to step up coordination of Member States’ economic, tax and social policies with a view to attracting foreign investment. The report also recommends making full and effective use of innovative investment measures. I voted in favour of this report in the July part-session.

intervention.name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
intervention.p: Ensuring that investing in Europe is competitive should be a priority for the European institutions, particularly in view of the current crisis. Increasing the level of investment and, in particular, of foreign direct investment, would stimulate the economies of the Member States and reduce the negative effects of fiscal consolidation. Therefore, I support initiatives involving continued funding of cohesion policy, because cohesion policy increases competitiveness and attracts investment to less-developed regions.

Facilitating the access of small and medium-sized enterprises to finance is a key factor in increasing investment. This not only involves fighting the credit crunch, but also ensuring alternative ways for SMEs to raise capital, such as by accessing European venture capital funds. However, regulation of such funds should aim to impose requirements which would reduce investment risk.

Stimulating research and innovation is also extremely important for the growth of investment in this area in the EU, as it has particular potential, mainly because of its qualified workforce. However, the introduction of a single EU patent, although a good idea, may also have negative consequences. Introducing this kind of single patent would mean a dramatic rise in the number of patents in all Member States, which could place significant restrictions on enterprises and, as a result, reduce investment. For this reason, I think further debate is needed on this matter.

intervention.name: Sergej KOZLÍK
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: At present, Europe needs to respond adequately to the challenges of stabilising the international economy. The EU is the world’s largest trading bloc and Europe remains the largest regional destination for foreign direct investment (FDI). EU flows are dominated by the US which, in 2008, accounted for more than one third of the EU’s outward FDI. It was 25 times as high as the corresponding figure for China. Switzerland and Canada also accounted for a significant share of EU FDI flows. Attracting investment in Europe requires measures and reforms, both at European and national level. Together with the US, the EU financial markets continue to provide around three quarters of global financial services. The EP welcomes the measures in this area, as well as the proposal to establish a European venture capital fund. I support Parliament’s position on improving the attractiveness of investing in Europe.

intervention.name: Giovanni LA VIA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The European Union is the most important area from the point of view of the economic and productive sector. Nevertheless, partly as a result of the crisis, our region has latterly lost the attractive features that had made it a leading player. Making investment in Europe more attractive will require political action on several fronts. We must improve the way the single market works, make maximum use of the opportunities afforded to us by cohesion policy, and take full advantage of the new means represented by project bonds. Political determination on all fronts, starting with effective communication and using tourism as a lever by promoting our rich cultural heritage, unique in the world, is the road we must stick to faithfully in order to play an active part in the process of reform that we need to exit from the crisis, by promoting the ‘made in Europe’ and ‘made in Italy’ brands.

intervention.name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
intervention.p: Despite continually rising youth unemployment, no measures are in evidence which might change the situation. There is a lack of special programmes to help young people, and not just at European level, because specific and effective measures are also lacking at national level. Europe faces the problem of an ageing society and, in a few years’ time, this is going to be a serious social and economic problem. The low level of economic growth and the high costs of labour are discouraging investment in this part of Europe. I think we need to react quickly to these worrying signs. We need to make the European market more attractive, because the regions have a great deal of untapped potential which is often not even noticed.

Cohesion policy should be the key to solving macro-economic and regional problems, leading to higher competitiveness and economic growth in the regions and the creation of much-needed new jobs, in particular, for young people. I think the Kratsa-Tsagaropoulou report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe is a good one, so I voted in favour of its adoption.

intervention.name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted for the report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe because it plays a key role in boosting competitiveness, productivity and the potential for economic growth. We need as much investment as possible, both in infrastructure and innovation, and in scientific and social initiatives.

The EU’s cohesion policy makes a significant contribution to the European economy and is one of the largest EU sources of investment. The Commission and Member States need to table specific measures for supporting all the companies offering jobs under the Europe 2020 strategy and in line with national and regional development strategies, and to ensure that funding decisions are based on the quality of the project and on its value to the strategies at national, regional, local and EU level.

I would also like to stress that a discriminatory approach towards large companies could hamper innovation and reduce the competitiveness of other EU companies – by this I mean SMEs in particular – by excluding the latter from vital global partnerships in collaborative innovation and by reducing their access to state of the art technology.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for this report, which welcomes the ECB’s longer-term refinancing operations (LTRO); calls on the ECB to further act in a decisive way in addressing the current euro area debt crisis by maintaining price stability while, at the same time, minimising negative spill-over effects on the real economy and the investments that the banking sector’s liquidity problems might generate; believes that the banking sector must take the necessary steps to address its structural weaknesses with regard to longer-term liquidity risks in order to restore investor confidence and therefore to avoid the need for the ECB to intervene so massively in future; considers that the bank’s operational framework should be shaped in such a way that a proportion of the grants would be made available for development purposes and to support small and medium-sized enterprises.

intervention.name: Clemente MASTELLA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Europe needs to respond adequately to the challenges of stabilising the international economy in order to exploit global opportunities to the maximum. We must address our weaknesses and strengthen the advantages of all countries and regions to attract local and international investment that will contribute to our balanced growth and our cohesion. The Union is the world’s largest trading power and remains the largest regional destination for foreign direct investment. Nevertheless, we must be capable of exploiting our competitive advantages, given the rising competition from developing countries. This goal must be at the heart of the EU’s investment reforms and strategy, at both European and national levels. At the global level, the EU must continue its efforts to conclude bilateral and multilateral free trade agreements as well as participate actively in global economic governance. Attracting investment in Europe needs measures and reforms, at both European and national levels. Ensuring that businesses can compete openly and fairly is crucial with respect to making Europe an attractive place in which to invest and work. The single market is one of the most significant priorities in developing a friendly and motivational environment for businesses and consumers.

intervention.name: Véronique MATHIEU HOUILLON
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe as, whilst we may be able to congratulate ourselves on the fact that Europe represents the top destination worldwide in terms of foreign direct investment, we still need to take measures to maintain the conditions favourable to these investments. In fact, the debt crisis and the lack of national investments could worry foreign investors. The report proposes a series of recommendations, including an integrated investment strategy within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy.

intervention.name: Iosif MATULA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted for the report from Rodi Kratsa-Tsagaropoulou because I think that, during the current economic and financial crisis, it is vital for us to focus our attention on attracting the largest volume possible not only of foreign investment, but also of local investment in the European Union. I think that investment in training for workers, promoting the entrepreneurial spirit and encouraging a favourable environment for small entrepreneurs are key elements in terms of the EU’s ability to attract foreign direct investment.

I would like to highlight the need to ease the administrative burden faced by small and medium-sized enterprises as part of the process of accessing European funds. At the same time, developing and encouraging public-private investments and the effective use of structural instruments for promoting economic recovery are crucial to attracting and retaining foreign and domestic capital in the European Union. However, we cannot talk about attracting investment in Europe without considering the creation of a climate conducive to investment through sustained economic growth. Consequently, rules need to be applied guaranteeing both fair competition and a fair competitive environment.

intervention.name: Mairead McGUINNESS
intervention.p: This report contains references to the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) and the simultaneous coordination of tax systems throughout Europe. I abstained on the final vote of this report, since taxation matters remain the competence of Member States.

intervention.name: Alajos MÉSZÁROS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Structural problems, rising unemployment and uncertainty continue to have a negative impact on our ability to deal with global growth challenges. In order for Europe to become more attractive to investors, these deficiencies need to be addressed, and measures and reforms need to be implemented both at European and at national level. Due to uncertainty, banks are experiencing financing difficulties, and resolute measures are therefore needed to enhance the financial markets. I agree that the European Union economy needs a financial sector that supports real economies, ensures stability, and is able to serve the needs of households and enterprises. SMEs are facing increasing difficulties in obtaining financing, and Member States should therefore implement regulatory measures that facilitate SME financing, seeing as how SMEs often act as drivers of local growth. The appropriate financing of cohesion policy is also important because it contributes to emphasising the benefits and innovation potential of regions and to highlighting their importance to growth, investment and employment. By promoting cultural industries, sport and tourism, which represent growing and attractive markets, we should also exploit the potential that lies in our historic heritage. I agree with the rapporteur, and therefore voted in favour of the report. Investments must be aimed at addressing the specific needs of the various regions and Member States while appropriately involving local communities.

intervention.name: Louis MICHEL
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: The economic crisis that the European Union is experiencing, accompanied by low levels of growth and high levels of unemployment, has increased the economic, social and investment disparities between the Member States. The underdeveloped regions are benefiting from substantial European funding to attract potential investors and will continue to benefit from them. Solidarity, however, requires growth. The social acquis are the result of a high-performance economy. Social protection can only ever be the consequence of work and responsibility. We must make investment the central component of our European policies. We need an economic government that implements proactive policies to produce promising investments. We must complete the single market, the key driver of economic growth, by fully implementing the legislation on energy and services. We need the courage to restructure certain sectors. We must press for a more flexible mobilisation of the Structural Funds, promote the entrepreneurial spirit and provide access to funding. We have to resist the siren call of inward-looking economic protectionism which can only result in an illusory well-being. Whilst we need competitiveness, we also need solidarity.

intervention.name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The ongoing crisis highlights the urgent need to mobilise the Union’s policy to fully support growth and increase funding for the EU economy through investment. This, of course, is not achievable without the effective implementation of structural reforms in order to improve the business climate and create jobs in all regions of the EU. With its 500 million consumers, the European single market offers huge advantages for investors, and the EU therefore traditionally maintains a high potential to attract foreign direct investment. The European Union must know how to properly utilise the huge potential of the world’s largest single market when seeking a comprehensive solution for the debt crisis suffered by citizens and businesses. I believe, therefore, that in addition to making Europe an attractive destination for foreign investors, we must first create favourable business conditions for local entrepreneurs, who still face many obstacles in the internal market. Inward investment in the European Union should help not only to make the environment for foreign direct investment more attractive, but also help overall investment and business in the internal market by improving sustainable infrastructure for business, education, research and development. For these reasons, I support the report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe.

intervention.name: Alexander MIRSKY
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: This report calls on the Commission to present a strategy on how to make investment, in particular, foreign direct investment, in Europe more attractive. I voted in favour because I call on the Commission to start working seriously.

intervention.name: Andreas MÖLZER
intervention.p: The economic crisis has left behind noticeable traces in Europe, even though we are gradually seeing signs that the situation is becoming more stable. Nevertheless, high levels of debt and rising oil prices represent a further risk. In addition, Europe still has to deal with the bankrupt states in the euro area, which have such poor credit ratings that investors there are few and far between. Furthermore, American rating agencies are making decisions about the creditworthiness of European countries, which can, in turn, lead to difficulties with investment and finance. As long as countries like Greece, Spain and Portugal are continuing to cause monetary instability in the euro area, it is likely to be difficult to prevent economic and social inequalities between the countries in the area, which is what the rapporteur is calling for. This is why I have abstained.

intervention.name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: By voting in favour of this report, I am calling on the Commission to prepare a communication to evaluate and promote the attractiveness of investing in Europe. The economic, financial and budgetary crisis that the European Union is experiencing, high taxation and the economic and social disparities between the Member States and the regions are all factors that are putting a brake on foreign investment in Europe. This situation could deteriorate with growing competition from the emerging economies. The European Union needs to implement a strategy in order better to meet investor expectations.

intervention.name: Rolandas PAKSAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this resolution. In order to withstand competition from the emerging economies, we need to do our utmost to promote the attractiveness of investing in Europe. The Commission must therefore take immediate action and prepare a communication as a matter of urgency containing measures for enhancing the EU investment environment and recommendations to the Member States. Furthermore, it is very important to finally complete an effectively functioning internal market and modernise the European public procurement market.

intervention.name: Maria do Céu PATRÃO NEVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Weak economic growth in Europe, high taxation and excessive public debt are factors raising concerns among investors. However, the high quality and diversity of our human capital, the predictability of the business environment and the high potential in research and innovation all work to our market’s advantage and are factors that should be strengthened and enhanced. As I agree with this view, I am supporting the rapporteur’s request that the Commission draft a communication assessing and promoting the attractiveness of investing in Europe. This should include recommendations to the Member States and act as one of the bases for enhancing the EU investment environment. I voted for this report because of all of these facts.

intervention.name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
intervention.p: The EU is the world’s largest trading bloc and external trade has so far played a dynamic role in boosting growth, especially in the services sector. A quarter of the world’s total consumption and investment takes place within its expanding borders, although it is a reduced share compared to the past. Nevertheless, Europe’s weak economic growth, high taxation and high public debt accumulation raise concerns on the part of investors, which can be magnified in the face of global competition, especially from emerging economies, as well as the lack of opportunities to exploit the EU’s full potential. The crisis is a global one and calls for an international response, and reforms at both national and European levels are necessary in order to improve the functioning of the single market and fully exploit the Structural Funds. With the aim of increasing the attractiveness of the European market and providing Europe with a coherent political, economic and regulatory framework, based on sustainable growth targets, I am voting in favour.

intervention.name: Franck PROUST
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The one advantage of the crisis is that it makes us ask ourselves relevant questions. This report has the answers. That is why I voted in favour of it. However, let us use our strengths and our words wisely: It is not enough to identify all of the options available to us to attract investment in Europe and thus revive our economy. We have to focus our efforts on the texts which will have the force of law in the coming years. I wish, of course, to talk about the guidelines of the Europe 2020 strategy and of how they translate at national level. I wish, particularly, to talk about Horizon 2020, the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation, the COSME programme for enterprises and SMEs and reform of the Structural Funds. However, not everything is decided within Europe. We must show pragmatism towards the outside world and require products arriving in our territory to comply with the same health and social standards as our own products. Otherwise, we have unfair competition. We must impose reciprocity in our trade. It is already there in the text of our agreements. Why is the Commission not doing anything?

intervention.name: Paulo RANGEL
intervention.p: In a situation of incipient economic growth, market instability and increased global imbalances, the EU needs to strengthen its competitive advantages in order to attract investment to the region, and thus promote balanced growth and greater cohesion. This report, for which I voted, calls on the Commission to draft a communication assessing and promoting the attractiveness of investing in Europe. This should include recommendations to the Member States and act as one of the bases for enhancing the EU investment environment. Despite being the world’s number one recipient of foreign direct investment, Europe needs to fix its weaknesses and make the most of its advantages and strengths, given the increasing competition from developing countries. Weak economic growth in Europe, high taxation and high public debt consumption are factors which raise concerns among investors. However, the high quality and diversity of our human capital, the predictability of the business environment and the high potential in research and innovation all work to our market’s advantage, and are factors that should be strengthened and enhanced.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: In favour. This is a relatively uncontroversial own-initiative report calling on the Commission and the Member States to take action to make Europe more attractive to outside investors. Key points in the report are: (i) Maximising cohesion policy benefits through highlighting the regions’ comparative advantages and innovation opportunities and their importance for growth, investment and employment and promoting the use of EU funds as a catalyst for attracting additional financing from the EIB, EBRD, other international financial institutions and the private sector; (ii) Addressing human capital needs and potential through the promotion of high-quality education institutions and education and professional training and the mobility of students, researchers, professors and workers; (iii) Ensuring stability and improving access to finance through the EU taking a more active role and committing to a globally coordinated regulatory response and closer cross-border cooperation, making banks more robust and promoting equity financing to reduce dependence on banks, among others.

intervention.name: Licia RONZULLI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report as I believe that it identifies the most appropriate guidelines for a new common policy that will make Europe capable of attracting investment and capital from the rest of the world. In order to achieve this objective, we need structural reforms at both national and international levels and a new regulatory framework to enhance the competitiveness of businesses in Europe through growth and jobs, while addressing the macro-economic and social imbalances that still remain between different areas.

intervention.name: Nikolaos SALAVRAKOS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: Europe remains the largest regional destination for foreign direct investment (FDI). I voted in favour of this report as it proposes ideas and measures to promote the attractiveness of investing in Europe, including policy recommendations to Member States targeted at enhancing the EU investment environment.

intervention.name: Edward SCICLUNA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: This report is particularly timely. With most European economies either stagnating or in recession, investment in the EU is badly needed. However, although there are many good proposals in this report, I and my delegation cannot support the proposal on harmonising the corporate tax base and we have therefore opted to abstain. Taxation policy remains a matter for Member States and, in any case, there are many more pressing priorities if we are to attract new investment. Most important is the need to complete the single market. More than twenty years after its creation, the single market – particularly in the services sector – is fragmented and differs from country to country. As a result of this, there are a number of Member States where it is very hard to start a business. Without a level playing field for businesses to operate in, we will continue to lose billions of euro of potential business activity. We need to make it easier for companies to do business in Europe and to make payments easier and faster, through closer cooperation in implementing rules on VAT and avoiding double taxation and by reducing the bureaucratic burden, particularly on small businesses. This will help to attract investment and drive our economic recovery.

intervention.name: Sergio Paolo Francesco SILVESTRIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: High debt levels in developed markets and rising oil prices are key risks ahead. The international economic environment has continued to be characterised by an uneven performance, weak growth in advanced economies and a stronger, although slowing, expansion in emerging markets. Structural problems, insufficient global rebalancing, a persistent development gap, rising unemployment, high public and private debt and uncertainty continue to adversely affect global growth prospects. While volatility in international financial markets has subsided, it remains high and action is needed to further reduce downside risks. With this vote, we will try to encourage and attract investments in Europe and this requires measures and reforms at both European and national level. Ensuring that businesses can compete openly and honestly is crucial with respect to making Europe an attractive place to invest and work.

intervention.name: Kay SWINBURNE
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: The ECR Group has decided to abstain on this own-initiative report, despite many valuable points developed therein. We welcome the fact that the EU remains the largest regional destination for foreign direct investment (FDI), despite the slowdown in investment flows as a result of the lingering global crisis. Investors appreciate the investment opportunities of the EU single market, mainly due to its high-quality and diverse human capital, relatively predictable business environment and high potential in research and innovation. We concur with the rapporteur that more needs to be done to overcome the burden of high taxation and high public debt accumulation, which have resulted in a loss of EU competitiveness at global level such as to eliminate restrictions on the supply of venture capital funding in small and medium-sized enterprises. We also agree that promoting education, research and development and job creation in areas such as greenhouse gas emissions reduction, development of renewable energy sources and improvement of energy efficiency could contribute to attracting FDI in the EU. Nevertheless, we object to the outright call for the implementation of a directive on the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) in the EU, as mentioned in paragraph 32 of the report.

intervention.name: Nuno TEIXEIRA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The crisis affecting the EU and the world in general has highlighted the need for the EU to take a good look at itself in order to identify the challenges that it is facing and enhance the ways it benefits its main trading partners. Globalisation also requires that the different actors coordinate with one another on the various macro-economic and financial policies. This report lists several areas in which the EU and the Member States should increase their effectiveness and/or rethink their strategies. The rapporteur highlights a number of elements as essential to attracting direct investment to Europe: maximising the benefits of cohesion policy, in order to attract additional funding from innovative financial instruments, and suggesting strategies to develop human capital, such as modernising labour markets and education systems, underpinned by knowledge based on innovation and research. The report also reaffirms that the stability of the euro area and greater intervention in the financial system by the European Central Bank are necessary, as the credit crunch is adversely affecting the real economy. Lastly, I would like to highlight the importance of investment in transport infrastructure, energy and information and communication technology in order to increase Europe’s long-term competitiveness.

intervention.name: Silvia-Adriana ȚICĂU
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the resolution on the attractiveness of investing in Europe because the economic, financial and fiscal crisis in the EU has significantly widened the economic and social disparities among Member States and regions, resulting in an uneven distribution of inward and outward investment across the European Union. I support the objectives of the Innovation Union and I call on Member States to set themselves a goal of increasing investment in education, research and innovation, given the medium- and long-term positive effects these areas can have on growth and development. The EU should also promote the Trans-European Networks and worker, student and researcher mobility, and reinforce cooperation and complementary features between EU economies. I called on the Commission and Member States to implement the ‘European eGovernment Action Plan’, enabling them to provide eGovernment services more efficiently and at a lower cost, including to companies, at both local and cross-border level. I think that the EU and Member States should take action particularly to increase utilisation of the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Fund as a catalyst for attracting additional funding from the EIB, EBRD, other international financial institutions and the private sector, while encouraging initiatives based on public-private partnerships.

intervention.name: Patrizia TOIA
intervention.p: I support this report because it is essential to attract new investors to the EU market. This is only possible through measures such as project bonds and far-reaching reforms such as the cohesion policy reform that we will adopt in 2013. Ambitious territorial development policies will allow the EU to maintain its high-quality human capital and foster an open and fair business environment as well as investment in research and innovation for successful products and business models, for the benefit of Europe’s economy and society.

The promotion of a strong industrial base needs to be put at the centre of reforms, particularly in those areas where the EU has traditionally been strong, as well as in high-tech sectors where a strong industrial base is essential to develop innovation in products, processes and services and to create new jobs. In a context of economic recovery, it is necessary to adopt ambitious legislation for SMEs by simplifying regulations and strengthening access to finance, promoting effective capital systems (venture and angel), and enhancing the role of private and public equity investments in financing long-term corporate growth. Parliament’s commitment will be maximal.

intervention.name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: In the context of deep recession in some parts of Europe, it is important that in addition to the much needed structural reforms to make our economies more competitive, we take the time to think of how to attract more foreign investment into our continent.

Europe has to take advantage of its special historical and cultural characteristics and, at the same time, promote SMEs and allow regions to develop their own policies to attract investors. An approach based on one size fits all is doomed to fail.

intervention.name: Derek VAUGHAN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Investment in Europe and, in particular, foreign direct investment, is hugely important to Europe’s economy. This report, which I voted in favour of, calls on the Commission to present a strategy to make investment in Europe more attractive. Cohesion policy investment is vital to this, as is creating a more robust European industrial policy. I fully support the report’s call for the greater use of innovative financial instruments and its emphasis on the need to facilitate workers’ and citizens’ mobility, which is vital to ensuring further investment in jobs.

intervention.name: Angelika WERTHMANN
intervention.p: The report discusses the position of the EU in the global economy as well as the consequences of this role, including challenges and duties. Certain goals like the development of infrastructure for companies, education and research, support for SMEs and the protection of employees are to be supported. Promotion of the European market’s attractiveness for international investors helps in the improvement of economic performance as well as the decline of unemployment rates.

intervention.name: Jacek WŁOSOWICZ
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: The most serious tax issues that Europeans face in cross-border situations are discrimination, double taxation and difficulties in claiming tax refunds and in obtaining information on foreign tax rules. I agree with the rapporteur, who believes that tax coordination should be an integral part of a growth strategy and that the Euro Plus Pact is correct in emphasising the importance of tax reforms.

Regarding corporate taxation, I, too, think that a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base will contribute to addressing some serious fiscal obstacles to growth in the single market which create disincentives for investment in the EU. Therefore, any strategies for boosting the EU’s attractiveness to foreign investors should be based on an assessment of achievements and deficiencies related to completion of the internal market.

intervention.name: Charalampos ANGOURAKIS
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: The report lays out the entire imperialist EU strategy east of the border with the Eastern partnership, through the trade links developed by the EU within that framework. The flagship proposal in the report is the establishment and development between the EU and every other country of a so-called ‘Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area’ (DCFTA) and ‘investment protection’, which really means the penetration of the euro-unifying monopolies throughout the Eastern partnership. It puts pressure on all the Eastern partners to join the WTO. It calls on the EU to step up efforts to enter into free trade agreements (FTAs), in a bid to neutralise Russian influence on these countries, thereby expressing the stiff competition between euro-unifying and Russian monopolies trying to gain a foothold on the emerging markets in the area. It openly proclaims that the EU must use these FTAs to intervene in these countries, including politically, on the pretext of democracy and human rights. It is especially insulting of Belarus, which it calls upon to join the WTO. It supports restrictive measures by the EU against that country and calls on the EU to step up aid to various NGOs and ‘civil society’, in the aim of imposing the political regime of its choice, so as to ‘eliminate obstacles to business’.

intervention.name: Pino ARLACCHI
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: I voted for this report because it stresses that the conclusion and the implementation of the association agreements is a priority of the reviewed European Neighbourhood Policy regarding the Eastern partners. The creation of Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) is indeed one of the most ambitious tools of EU bilateral trade policy with the aim to achieve a stable economic environment which respects democracy and the rule of law. In addition, it is important to underline that prosperity and stability in the EU’s eastern neighbourhood are in the EU’s utmost interest and, moreover, I believe that stable relations between the EU and its Eastern partners will undoubtedly increase trade volumes in both directions.

intervention.name: Sophie AUCONIE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Six ex-USSR republics – Ukraine Belarus, Moldova, Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia – are associated with the European Union within the framework of the Eastern partnership. The main objective of this partnership is to support these countries in the pursuit of a democratic transition to avoid conflicts in the region, by opening up some areas of the single market. I supported the recommendations for each country, which differ in accordance with the democratic progress and respect for the principles of the rule of law in each. We have called for Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas whilst introducing the ‘more for more’ principle, a new concept which creates a link between political progress on the road to wide-ranging democratisation and economic liberalisation of trade.

intervention.name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of association agreements with the Eastern partnership’s trading partners in order to establish a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area. As China’s impact on European trade is growing and Russia continues to engage in protectionist policies, the EU’s European Neighbourhood Policy with Eastern partners is one of the Union’s priority aims. I believe that the prospect of creating Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) with the EU is one of the greatest ambitions of EU bilateral trade policy for fighting tendencies towards protectionism at global level. The development of Eastern partnership trade is essential for avoiding regional conflicts in future, which lead to economic isolation. The development of trade relations with the Eastern partners is therefore important not just economically; its impact covers issues relating to the development of democracy, the rule of law and common EU principles. I believe that in the long term, the benefits of integration should compensate the Eastern partners for the efforts they have made.

intervention.name: Mara BIZZOTTO
intervention.p: I support Mr Ransdorf’s report on the Eastern partnership, which provides a framework for relations between the EU and Armenia, Georgia, Moldova, Ukraine, Azerbaijan and Belarus. Among them, the first four are already members of the World Trade Organisation whilst the last two are only observers. From the socio-political point of view, this area is still unstable, but the EU cannot avoid introducing partnership policies with it. This is, in fact, an area dominated by Russian influence and extremely rich in energy resources. Finally, it is likely that this type of EU policy will encourage these countries to carry out the much desired institutional reforms and modernisation.

intervention.name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report because the conclusion and implementation of association agreements including Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) is a priority aim and ambition of the reviewed European Neighbourhood Policy regarding the Eastern partners. Only four out of the six countries of the Eastern partnership are already members of the WTO, with the governments of Azerbaijan and Belarus having only observer status. However, all EU Eastern partners, being the ex-USSR states, share the same historical and institutional background. They have also faced similar challenges in their political and socio-economic transition over the past two decades. Furthermore, following the revolutionary events which took place in 2011 in the European Union’s Southern neighbourhood, EU interest has been focused on the southern neighbours and the countries belonging to the Eastern partnership and EU trade relations with them deserve the attention of the EU. Prosperity and stability in the EU’s eastern neighbourhood are in the EU’s utmost interest. As stable and predictable relations between the EU and its Eastern partners develop, trade volumes will undoubtedly increase in both directions. There needs to be an ambitious approach to integrating the economies of the EU and of the Eastern partnership countries through DCFTAs by including other aspects related to free and fair trade.

intervention.name: Philippe BOULLAND
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report on the trade aspects of the Eastern partnership, which follows on from the joint communication from the European institutions on ‘a new response to a changing neighbourhood’. The Eastern partnership consists of the European Union, on the one hand and, on the other, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. As the EU is the main export market and the main source of imports for these countries, it was important to introduce new trade agreements suited to changing economic needs and capacities. Moreover, these agreements are in line with the idea of the ‘more for more’ principle. This concept creates a link between political progress on the road to wide-ranging democratisation and the economic liberalisation of trade. This report also stresses the need for regulatory convergence, with the aim of achieving gradual economic integration with the EU’s single market. This report, therefore, sends a strong political and economic signal to the countries in the Eastern partnership and stresses our commitment to them.

intervention.name: Arkadiusz Tomasz BRATKOWSKI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I welcome the result of today’s vote on the report on the trade aspects of the Eastern partnership. During my many years in politics, I have had occasion to be involved in cross-border cooperation in Poland’s relations with Belarus and Ukraine. I have also been able to see the mutual benefits of this cooperation, and they are not just political and economic benefits, because they are also – if not primarily – social benefits.

Forging closer economic relations with Eastern partnership countries by creating free trade areas can, in the long term, facilitate effective implementation of EU foreign policy and help consolidate the European model of democracy and the economy.

However, building closer economic relations in a way which offers benefits to both sides should not be done without attaching conditions. Therefore, making specific recommendations to the EU’s neighbours referred to in the document will allow comprehensive aid programmes to be put in place and lasting relations to be built with credible partners who are conscious of our clearly defined expectations.

intervention.name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
intervention.p: The creation of Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas with the EU is one of the main incentives for partner countries – namely Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan – to pursue democratic reform, economic stabilisation and integration, transparency and trade regulation. These partnerships are a priority objective of the European Neighbourhood Policy with regard to its Eastern partners. I voted for the report, as I consider it vital to pursue the further deepening of the European Neighbourhood Policy in relation to our Eastern partners, namely, Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan.

intervention.name: Marielle de SARNEZ
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe - Vice
intervention.p: Today, the EU is the main trading partner of Ukraine, Belarus, Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan and Moldova. These countries must therefore transpose the standards required under the Eastern partnership neighbourhood instrument into their national legislations. However, we need to be aware that some of them, such as Belarus, under the yoke of an implacable dictatorship, or Ukraine, which is struggling to install a solid rule of law, are facing major political and economic difficulties. It is therefore up to the European Union to contribute to the introduction of a stable legal and economic environment in these countries.

intervention.name: Christine DE VEYRAC
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted for this report, which supports the development of trade cooperation with our Eastern neighbours built on a win-win basis. The intensification of trade with these former Soviet countries will, in fact, allow us to secure our energy supplies whilst offering potential new openings to our companies. At the same time, these countries will be able to take advantage of our partnership to develop and diversify their economies and strengthen their democracy.

intervention.name: Ioan ENCIU
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the trade aspects of the Eastern partnership because it highlights the importance of DCFTAs as a vital trade instrument for building up economic relationships with third countries.

It also contains a very important analysis of the ongoing trade, economic and social situation of the ongoing negotiations on the EU-Ukraine, EU-Moldova, EU-Georgia, EU-Armenia and EU-Azerbaijan association agreements.

I particularly welcome the underlined DCFTAs potential for conflict prevention through economic and social cohesion, which relies on the ‘more for more’ principle as the appropriate instrument for acknowledging the efforts of those who make the most progress and motivating others to step up their efforts.

The report expresses the need for the economic integration of the Eastern partners with the EU to be carried out according to the necessary political and social reforms, and that institution building and proper implementation of commitments are prerequisites for the successful implementation of DCFTAs.

intervention.name: Edite ESTRELA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for the report on ‘trade aspects of the Eastern partnership’, as I consider the general and specific recommendations of each country to be positive in relation to the negotiation of deep and comprehensive agreements, the importance of technical assistance, the alignment of legislation, environmental standards and the involvement of civil society.

intervention.name: Diogo FEIO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: It is a cliché to say that trading partners do not go to war. Moreover, it is a cliché that does not even reflect the truth. Nonetheless, the truth is that conflicts between these sorts of partners tend to be fewer and the partners often aim to exhaust means of dialogue before resorting to war. Following years of tension on their eastern borders due to the Cold War and the Sovietisation of the region, it is reassuring to note that, despite the differences and disparities between the EU and its Eastern partners, there is a willingness today to prioritise trade issues and to seek an increasingly close relationship which is productive for all parties. It will not do to ignore the fact that there is still a long way to go, in particular, with regard to issues of democracy, human rights and combating corruption and violence, but it is right to acknowledge the work that has been done and some successes that have been achieved. I hope that this partnership will develop to the satisfaction of all parties, and that it will enable economic growth for all and closer relations between the different peoples and cultures, with respect for their respective identities.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: Mr Ransdorf’s report aims to promote and strengthen trade relations in the EU’s Eastern partnership. Over recent decades, the EU has favoured trade relations with eastern countries while encouraging democratisation and seeking to implement respect for fundamental human rights. This is an important partnership for these countries, but it is also vital for the EU in overcoming certain problems that the eastern Member States are facing. It is vital to resolve the problem of the pipeline with Moldova, open energy corridors and overcome visa-related issues with Ukraine. In relation to Georgia, although the President’s democratic ideals are well known, it is necessary to press ahead with the social reforms under way in order to end the scourge that is child labour. I welcome the establishment of this new Eastern partnership, with an agreement that covers not only trade in goods but also other areas such as increased solidarity and non-tariff barriers, as the EU should continue to support these peoples in order to ensure close integration which is always based on full respect for the rule of law and democracy.

intervention.name: João FERREIRA
intervention.p: The majority in Parliament is going full steam ahead along a course that has been shown, in the reality of the EU as the largest free trade area in the world, to make no contribution towards resolving any of the problems that the workers and peoples are facing. The insistence on the free movement of goods and capital between the EU and these countries, and the ‘integration’ of the markets of the Eastern partnership countries advocated here, through the creation of ‘Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas’, only benefits the companies with a dominant position in production and marketing. The consequences of this are well known due to what has happened in Portugal: the destruction of small and medium-sized enterprises and national production, creating even more unemployment, and the destruction of workers’ rights. Moreover, as the situation of the EU demonstrates, ‘free trade’ has impacts that go far beyond purely trade issues, also influencing the state of democracy, and we believe that this is for the worse. ‘Free trade’ encourages the concentration and centralisation of the wealth of economically richer countries and their companies, and it runs counter to the development of fairer trade relations based on sovereignty, protection and increased national production, which can only be safeguarded by trade relations based on complementarity between countries.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: Following the recent events, generally known as the Arab Spring, our attention has become focused on the European Union’s southern neighbours. However Eastern partnership countries and EU trade relations with these countries cannot be overlooked. Our eastern neighbours are the ex-USSR states. They share the same historical background and, over the past twenty years, they have been working towards a political and socio-democratic transition. Four out of the six countries of the EU’s Eastern partnership are already members of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), and the remaining two countries have observer status. The primary aim in this respect of the EU’s Neighbourhood Policy is the conclusion and implementation of agreements involving the issue of free trade – DCFTA agreements. These are of the utmost importance in the EU’s bilateral trade policy and in line with our efforts to achieve a stable, transparent and predictable economic environment. They are also fundamental in the fight against protectionism at a global level. They also reach far beyond trade issues and influence the state of democracy and the rule of law. I believe it is important to focus on the gradual dismantling of trade barriers, the strengthening of investment protection, the streamlining of customs and border procedures and the restriction of technical barriers to trade. The Eastern partnership countries are our strategic partners and, in this context, efforts to prevent conflicts by means of economic and social cohesion must be one of our priorities.

intervention.name: Juozas IMBRASAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report on the trade aspects of the Eastern partnership because the prospect of creating Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) with the EU is one of the key incentives for the partner countries to pursue their reform efforts. I believe that the creation of DCFTAs is one of the most ambitious tools of EU bilateral trade policy for achieving a stable, transparent and predictable economic environment which respects democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law, providing not only for greater economic integration by a gradual dismantling of trade barriers, but also for regulatory convergence in areas that have an impact on trade in goods and services, in particular, by strengthening investment protection, streamlining customs and border procedures, reducing technical and other non-tariff barriers to trade, strengthening sanitary and phytosanitary rules, improving animal welfare, enhancing the legal frameworks for competition and public procurement and ensuring sustainable development.

intervention.name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Trade is a vitally important aspect of the EU’s relations with the countries in the Eastern partnership. Trade agreements are crucial instruments for building long-term economic relations with our Eastern partners and help promote economic reforms, the rule of law and social and environmental standards on our doorstep. I think that our Eastern partners cannot achieve economic integration with the EU effectively without political and social reforms and without civil society being involved in the decision-making process and economic integration being achieved even among the Eastern partners, a point actually emphasised as well by the report. The report also notes that national parliaments have an important role to play as well in harmonising trade legislation with the EU acquis , which is a prerequisite for concluding and implementing future agreements properly. There are countries in the Eastern partnership which have made remarkable progress, such as the Republic of Moldova. The report recognises with satisfaction that Moldova, despite the fragility of its economy, has, in recent years, undergone a remarkable reform process and hugely improved its economic performance. This highlights, in this regard, the vital importance of the financial assistance provided by the International Monetary Fund and the macro-financial assistance provided by the EU. These are some of the reasons why I support this report.

intervention.name: Philippe JUVIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: For the majority of its neighbours, the European Union is the main export market and the main source of imports. This trade in goods and services plays a significant role in economic growth. The conclusion of ambitious European Union agreements with these countries is therefore essential. Hence, the most suitable and most effective method for strengthening these trade links is to establish a free trade area. The report provides for the gradual dismantling of trade barriers and seeks to bring about convergence of trade-related regulations. I voted in favour of this report.

intervention.name: Michał Tomasz KAMIŃSKI
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: I endorsed this report because I am firmly convinced that the prospect of opening Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas with the EU is the main incentive for partner countries to continue reforms. In recent years, Moldova has been through an exceptional series of reforms and has taken far-reaching steps towards European integration. I would also like to mention Georgia, one of the fastest-reforming economies in the world. Georgia is in a very specific situation as regards DCFTA negotiations and certain requirements and regulations laid down by the Commission. The Georgians have – in many cases quite rightly – closed down many bodies which had responsibility for oversight and inspection, as these were perceived as remnants of the Soviet system. This means that what the EU says are institutions which monitor standards often seem to the Georgians to be the corrupt legacy of Communism. The EU is Belarus’s second largest trading partner after Russia. It is true that our eastern neighbour has undoubted potential. I am certain that Belarusian citizens deserve to belong to the European family of democratic and free market states. Unfortunately, Minsk is moving ever further away from the EU in terms of political and economic standards. Furthermore, the Belarusian economic model, in which 80% of enterprises are owned by the state, leaves a great deal to be desired. So, when we are talking about Belarus and the commercial aspect of the Eastern partnership, a DCFTA, unfortunately, has to be put off to another day.

intervention.name: Giovanni LA VIA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Trade relations with the EU’s Eastern partners are an important aspect of our economic policies and must be carefully monitored in order to allow for their improvement. In particular, the creation of Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) in the east represents a basket of economic and trade opportunities, with multiple implications for our operators, in particular, small and medium-sized enterprises and the tourism industry, provided that reciprocity is respected in important areas such as compliance with the same rules on security and control. It is clear that through the creation of free trade areas, we want to act not only at the economic level but also at the political and social levels of the countries involved in the trade partnership. There is no doubt that, in order to achieve a proper industrial development strategy, we must first implement cooperation aimed at improving the civil and political characteristics that can allow for the maximum expression of individual freedom.

intervention.name: Petru Constantin LUHAN
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: With regard to the trade aspects of the whole Eastern partnership, establishing Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) with the EU will definitely produce tangible long-term benefits for all stakeholders. However, I think that the measures for some key sectors of activity supporting these states’ economic development must be examined and regulated more widely from the perspective of the EU’s policies, such as the SME sector and research and innovation. I am concerned about the unstable political and economic situation in some of the states in the region, which needs to be closely monitored. This is why I think that we need to be cautious but, at the same time, continue the steps involving the flexible economic arrangements given to the relevant countries, as well as the institutional support.

intervention.name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
intervention.p: The report on the trade aspects of the Eastern partnership is about important international issues, and it underscores efforts to strengthen the Eastern partnership countries. Personally, I think that trade agreements, apart from the fact that they impose conditions on the respective parties, also bring many benefits. By stimulating economic growth, they provide benefits to consumers, businesses and employees, and they also stimulate institutional reforms, which, in consequence, lead to the modernisation of entire countries and regions.

As a member of the EU-Ukraine delegation, I would like to stress that Ukraine is Europe’s largest trading partner among the Eastern partnership countries and we should support the efforts being made by Ukrainian society and the country’s authorities to eliminate all social and political inequalities. For this reason, among others, I voted in favour of the Ransdorf report.

intervention.name: Monica MACOVEI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we must show our support to the countries of the Eastern partnership. The creation of Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas is a key incentive for democratisation. People who can trade more freely will discover on their own the advantages of a political system based on respect for the rule of law and democratic values. I also welcome the Commission’s proposal to increase by 40% the funding available for the eastern neighbourhood policy in the multiannual financial framework 2014-2021. We need to spend European taxpayers’ money in an effective way and reward high achievers. The Republic of Moldova has made considerable progress in the past year. This would not have been possible without the EU’s support. We need to continue our negotiations with the Eastern partners and open up new economic possibilities for their citizens. Financial support, free trade and strong conditionality are the tools the Union should use in promoting our values in the neighbourhood.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for this resolution, which ‘is convinced that the economic integration of the Eastern partners with the EU cannot be efficiently carried out without political and social reforms, participation of civil society in the decision-making process and economic integration among the Eastern partners themselves; emphasises that economic integration among these countries should be open, so as to capitalise on its benefits; regrets in this regard that regional frozen conflicts have, for many years, harmed the effectiveness and development of cross-border trade and continue to cause enormous economic losses to some of the Eastern partners and to lead to their economic isolation’.

intervention.name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
